rules.name: User Risk and MFA Registration Policy Updated
rules.description:
Detects changes and updates to the user risk and MFA registration policy.
Attackers can modified the policies to Bypass MFA, weaken security thresholds, facilitate further attacks, maintain persistence.

rules.name: Certificate-Based Authentication Enabled
rules.description: Detects when certificate based authentication has been enabled in an Azure Active Directory tenant.

rules.name: PIM Alert Setting Changes To Disabled
rules.description: Detects when PIM alerts are set to disabled.

rules.name: User Added To Group With CA Policy Modification Access
rules.description: Monitor and alert on group membership additions of groups that have CA policy modification access

rules.name: Changes to Device Registration Policy
rules.description: Monitor and alert for changes to the device registration policy.

rules.name: Delegated Permissions Granted For All Users
rules.description: Detects when highly privileged delegated permissions are granted on behalf of all users

rules.name: New Root Certificate Authority Added
rules.description: Detects newly added root certificate authority to an AzureAD tenant to support certificate based authentication.

rules.name: Azure AD Only Single Factor Authentication Required
rules.description: Detect when users are authenticating without MFA being required.

rules.name: Sign-ins by Unknown Devices
rules.description: Monitor and alert for Sign-ins by unknown devices from non-Trusted locations.

rules.name: Multifactor Authentication Denied
rules.description: User has indicated they haven't instigated the MFA prompt and could indicate an attacker has the password for the account.

rules.name: Sign-in Failure Due to Conditional Access Requirements Not Met
rules.description: Define a baseline threshold for failed sign-ins due to Conditional Access failures

rules.name: Suspicious SignIns From A Non Registered Device
rules.description: Detects risky authentication from a non AD registered device without MFA being required.

rules.name: Multifactor Authentication Interrupted
rules.description: Identifies user login with multifactor authentication failures, which might be an indication an attacker has the password for the account but can't pass the MFA challenge.

rules.name: Increased Failed Authentications Of Any Type
rules.description: Detects when sign-ins increased by 10% or greater.

rules.name: Measurable Increase Of Successful Authentications
rules.description: Detects when successful sign-ins increased by 10% or greater.

rules.name: Discovery Using AzureHound
rules.description: Detects AzureHound (A BloodHound data collector for Microsoft Azure) activity via the default User-Agent that is used during its operation after successful authentication.

rules.name: Sign-ins from Non-Compliant Devices
rules.description: Monitor and alert for sign-ins where the device was non-compliant.

rules.name: Use of Legacy Authentication Protocols
rules.description: Alert on when legacy authentication has been used on an account

rules.name: Device Registration or Join Without MFA
rules.description: Monitor and alert for device registration or join events where MFA was not performed.

rules.name: User Access Blocked by Azure Conditional Access
rules.description:
Detect access has been blocked by Conditional Access policies.
The access policy does not allow token issuance which might be sights of unauthorizeed login to valid accounts.

rules.name: Failed Authentications From Countries You Do Not Operate Out Of
rules.description: Detect failed authentications from countries you do not operate out of.

rules.name: Potential MFA Bypass Using Legacy Client Authentication
rules.description: Detects successful authentication from potential clients using legacy authentication via user agent strings. This could be a sign of MFA bypass using a password spray attack.

rules.name: Azure Unusual Authentication Interruption
rules.description: Detects when there is a interruption in the authentication process.

rules.name: Applications That Are Using ROPC Authentication Flow
rules.description:
Resource owner password credentials (ROPC) should be avoided if at all possible as this requires the user to expose their current password credentials to the application directly.
The application then uses those credentials to authenticate the user against the identity provider.

rules.name: Users Authenticating To Other Azure AD Tenants
rules.description: Detect when users in your Azure AD tenant are authenticating to other Azure AD Tenants.

rules.name: Application Using Device Code Authentication Flow
rules.description:
Device code flow is an OAuth 2.0 protocol flow specifically for input constrained devices and is not used in all environments.
If this type of flow is seen in the environment and not being used in an input constrained device scenario, further investigation is warranted.
This can be a misconfigured application or potentially something malicious.

rules.name: Account Lockout
rules.description: Identifies user account which has been locked because the user tried to sign in too many times with an incorrect user ID or password.

rules.name: Authentications To Important Apps Using Single Factor Authentication
rules.description: Detect when authentications to important application(s) only required single-factor authentication

rules.name: Login to Disabled Account
rules.description: Detect failed attempts to sign in to disabled accounts.

rules.name: Account Disabled or Blocked for Sign in Attempts
rules.description: Detects when an account is disabled or blocked for sign in but tried to log in

rules.name: Successful Authentications From Countries You Do Not Operate Out Of
rules.description: Detect successful authentications from countries you do not operate out of.

rules.name: Azure Kubernetes Pods Deleted
rules.description: Identifies the deletion of Azure Kubernetes Pods.

rules.name: Azure Device No Longer Managed or Compliant
rules.description: Identifies when a device in azure is no longer managed or compliant

rules.name: Number Of Resource Creation Or Deployment Activities
rules.description: Number of VM creations or deployment activities occur in Azure via the azureactivity log.

rules.name: Azure VPN Connection Modified or Deleted
rules.description: Identifies when a VPN connection is modified or deleted.

rules.name: Azure Firewall Rule Configuration Modified or Deleted
rules.description: Identifies when a Firewall Rule Configuration is Modified or Deleted.

rules.name: Azure Application Credential Modified
rules.description: Identifies when a application credential is modified.

rules.name: Disabled MFA to Bypass Authentication Mechanisms
rules.description: Detection for when multi factor authentication has been disabled, which might indicate a malicious activity to bypass authentication mechanisms.

rules.name: Azure Virtual Network Device Modified or Deleted
rules.description:
Identifies when a virtual network device is being modified or deleted.
This can be a network interface, network virtual appliance, virtual hub, or virtual router.

rules.name: Azure Kubernetes Cluster Created or Deleted
rules.description: Detects when a Azure Kubernetes Cluster is created or deleted.

rules.name: Azure Active Directory Hybrid Health AD FS New Server
rules.description:
This detection uses azureactivity logs (Administrative category) to identify the creation or update of a server instance in an Azure AD Hybrid health AD FS service.
A threat actor can create a new AD Health ADFS service and create a fake server instance to spoof AD FS signing logs. There is no need to compromise an on-prem AD FS server.
This can be done programmatically via HTTP requests to Azure.

rules.name: Azure New CloudShell Created
rules.description: Identifies when a new cloudshell is created inside of Azure portal.

rules.name: Azure Owner Removed From Application or Service Principal
rules.description: Identifies when a owner is was removed from a application or service principal in Azure.

rules.name: Azure Kubernetes Events Deleted
rules.description: Detects when Events are deleted in Azure Kubernetes. An adversary may delete events in Azure Kubernetes in an attempt to evade detection.

rules.name: Azure Kubernetes Service Account Modified or Deleted
rules.description: Identifies when a service account is modified or deleted.

rules.name: Azure Keyvault Key Modified or Deleted
rules.description: Identifies when a Keyvault Key is modified or deleted in Azure.

rules.name: Azure Kubernetes Network Policy Change
rules.description: Identifies when a Azure Kubernetes network policy is modified or deleted.

rules.name: Azure Kubernetes CronJob
rules.description:
Identifies when a Azure Kubernetes CronJob runs in Azure Cloud. Kubernetes Job is a controller that creates one or more pods and ensures that a specified number of them successfully terminate.
Kubernetes Job can be used to run containers that perform finite tasks for batch jobs. Kubernetes CronJob is used to schedule Jobs.
An Adversary may use Kubernetes CronJob for scheduling execution of malicious code that would run as a container in the cluster.

rules.name: Azure Firewall Rule Collection Modified or Deleted
rules.description: Identifies when Rule Collections (Application, NAT, and Network) is being modified or deleted.

rules.name: Azure Application Security Group Modified or Deleted
rules.description: Identifies when a application security group is modified or deleted.

rules.name: Azure Container Registry Created or Deleted
rules.description: Detects when a Container Registry is created or deleted.

rules.name: Azure Suppression Rule Created
rules.description: Identifies when a suppression rule is created in Azure. Adversary's could attempt this to evade detection.

rules.name: Azure Firewall Modified or Deleted
rules.description: Identifies when a firewall is created, modified, or deleted.

rules.name: Azure Kubernetes Secret or Config Object Access
rules.description: Identifies when a Kubernetes account access a sensitive objects such as configmaps or secrets.

rules.name: Azure Key Vault Modified or Deleted
rules.description: Identifies when a key vault is modified or deleted.

rules.name: Azure Device or Configuration Modified or Deleted
rules.description: Identifies when a device or device configuration in azure is modified or deleted.

rules.name: Azure Subscription Permission Elevation Via ActivityLogs
rules.description:
Detects when a user has been elevated to manage all Azure Subscriptions.
This change should be investigated immediately if it isn't planned.
This setting could allow an attacker access to Azure subscriptions in your environment.

rules.name: Azure Active Directory Hybrid Health AD FS Service Delete
rules.description:
This detection uses azureactivity logs (Administrative category) to identify the deletion of an Azure AD Hybrid health AD FS service instance in a tenant.
A threat actor can create a new AD Health ADFS service and create a fake server to spoof AD FS signing logs.
The health AD FS service can then be deleted after it is not longer needed via HTTP requests to Azure.

rules.name: Azure DNS Zone Modified or Deleted
rules.description: Identifies when DNS zone is modified or deleted.

rules.name: Azure Service Principal Created
rules.description: Identifies when a service principal is created in Azure.

rules.name: Azure Service Principal Removed
rules.description: Identifies when a service principal was removed in Azure.

rules.name: Azure Kubernetes Sensitive Role Access
rules.description: Identifies when ClusterRoles/Roles are being modified or deleted.

rules.name: User Added to an Administrator's Azure AD Role
rules.description: User Added to an Administrator's Azure AD Role

rules.name: Azure Point-to-site VPN Modified or Deleted
rules.description: Identifies when a Point-to-site VPN is Modified or Deleted.

rules.name: Azure Application Gateway Modified or Deleted
rules.description: Identifies when a application gateway is modified or deleted.

rules.name: Azure Kubernetes RoleBinding/ClusterRoleBinding Modified and Deleted
rules.description: Detects the creation or patching of potential malicious RoleBinding/ClusterRoleBinding.

rules.name: Azure Application Deleted
rules.description: Identifies when a application is deleted in Azure.

rules.name: Azure Kubernetes Admission Controller
rules.description:
Identifies when an admission controller is executed in Azure Kubernetes.
A Kubernetes Admission controller intercepts, and possibly modifies, requests to the Kubernetes API server.
The behavior of this admission controller is determined by an admission webhook (MutatingAdmissionWebhook or ValidatingAdmissionWebhook) that the user deploys in the cluster.
An adversary can use such webhooks as the MutatingAdmissionWebhook for obtaining persistence in the cluster.
For example, attackers can intercept and modify the pod creation operations in the cluster and add their malicious container to every created pod.
An adversary can use the webhook ValidatingAdmissionWebhook, which could be used to obtain access credentials.
An adversary could use the webhook to intercept the requests to the API server, record secrets, and other sensitive information.

rules.name: Granting Of Permissions To An Account
rules.description: Identifies IPs from which users grant access to other users on azure resources and alerts when a previously unseen source IP address is used.

rules.name: Rare Subscription-level Operations In Azure
rules.description: Identifies IPs from which users grant access to other users on azure resources and alerts when a previously unseen source IP address is used.

rules.name: Azure Network Security Configuration Modified or Deleted
rules.description: Identifies when a network security configuration is modified or deleted.

rules.name: Azure Network Firewall Policy Modified or Deleted
rules.description: Identifies when a Firewall Policy is Modified or Deleted.

rules.name: Azure Virtual Network Modified or Deleted
rules.description: Identifies when a Virtual Network is modified or deleted in Azure.

rules.name: Azure Keyvault Secrets Modified or Deleted
rules.description: Identifies when secrets are modified or deleted in Azure.

rules.name: Cisco Duo Successful MFA Authentication Via Bypass Code
rules.description:
Detects when a successful MFA authentication occurs due to the use of a bypass code.
A bypass code is a temporary passcode created by an administrator for a specific user to access a Duo-protected application. These are generally used as "backup codes," so that enrolled users who are having problems with their mobile devices (e.g., mobile service is disrupted, the device is lost or stolen, etc.) or who temporarily can't use their enrolled devices (on a plane without mobile data services) can still access their Duo-protected systems.

rules.name: Google Cloud DNS Zone Modified or Deleted
rules.description: Identifies when a DNS Zone is modified or deleted in Google Cloud.

rules.name: Google Cloud SQL Database Modified or Deleted
rules.description: Detect when a Cloud SQL DB has been modified or deleted.

rules.name: Google Cloud Firewall Modified or Deleted
rules.description: Detects  when a firewall rule is modified or deleted in Google Cloud Platform (GCP).

rules.name: Google Cloud Service Account Disabled or Deleted
rules.description: Identifies when a service account is disabled or deleted in Google Cloud.

rules.name: Google Cloud Kubernetes Secrets Modified or Deleted
rules.description: Identifies when the Secrets are Modified or Deleted.

rules.name: Google Cloud Kubernetes RoleBinding
rules.description: Detects the creation or patching of potential malicious RoleBinding. This includes RoleBindings and ClusterRoleBinding.

rules.name: Google Cloud Kubernetes Admission Controller
rules.description:
Identifies when an admission controller is executed in GCP Kubernetes.
A Kubernetes Admission controller intercepts, and possibly modifies, requests to the Kubernetes API server.
The behavior of this admission controller is determined by an admission webhook (MutatingAdmissionWebhook or ValidatingAdmissionWebhook) that the user deploys in the cluster.
An adversary can use such webhooks as the MutatingAdmissionWebhook for obtaining persistence in the cluster.
For example, attackers can intercept and modify the pod creation operations in the cluster and add their malicious container to every created pod. An adversary can use the webhook ValidatingAdmissionWebhook, which could be used to obtain access credentials.
An adversary could use the webhook to intercept the requests to the API server, record secrets, and other sensitive information.

rules.name: Google Cloud VPN Tunnel Modified or Deleted
rules.description: Identifies when a VPN Tunnel Modified or Deleted in Google Cloud.

rules.name: GCP Access Policy Deleted
rules.description:
Detects when an access policy that is applied to a GCP cloud resource is deleted.
An adversary would be able to remove access policies to gain access to a GCP cloud resource.

rules.name: Google Cloud Re-identifies Sensitive Information
rules.description: Identifies when sensitive information is re-identified in google Cloud.

rules.name: GCP Break-glass Container Workload Deployed
rules.description: Detects the deployment of workloads that are deployed by using the break-glass flag to override Binary Authorization controls.

rules.name: Google Cloud Storage Buckets Modified or Deleted
rules.description: Detects when storage bucket is modified or deleted in Google Cloud.

rules.name: Google Cloud Storage Buckets Enumeration
rules.description: Detects when storage bucket is enumerated in Google Cloud.

rules.name: Google Full Network Traffic Packet Capture
rules.description: Identifies potential full network packet capture in gcp. This feature can potentially be abused to read sensitive data from unencrypted internal traffic.

rules.name: Google Cloud Service Account Modified
rules.description: Identifies when a service account is modified in Google Cloud.

rules.name: Google Cloud Kubernetes CronJob
rules.description:
Identifies when a Google Cloud Kubernetes CronJob runs in Azure Cloud. Kubernetes Job is a controller that creates one or more pods and ensures that a specified number of them successfully terminate.
Kubernetes Job can be used to run containers that perform finite tasks for batch jobs. Kubernetes CronJob is used to schedule Jobs.
An Adversary may use Kubernetes CronJob for scheduling execution of malicious code that would run as a container in the cluster.

rules.name: Google Workspace Application Removed
rules.description: Detects when an an application is removed from Google Workspace.

rules.name: Google Workspace User Granted Admin Privileges
rules.description: Detects when an Google Workspace user is granted admin privileges.

rules.name: Google Workspace Application Access Level Modified
rules.description:
Detects when an access level is changed for a Google workspace application.
An access level is part of BeyondCorp Enterprise which is Google Workspace's way of enforcing Zero Trust model.
An adversary would be able to remove access levels to gain easier access to Google workspace resources.

rules.name: Google Workspace Role Modified or Deleted
rules.description: Detects when an a role is modified or deleted in Google Workspace.

rules.name: Google Workspace Granted Domain API Access
rules.description: Detects when an API access service account is granted domain authority.

rules.name: Google Workspace Role Privilege Deleted
rules.description: Detects when an a role privilege is deleted in Google Workspace.

rules.name: Google Workspace MFA Disabled
rules.description: Detects when multi-factor authentication (MFA) is disabled.

rules.name: OneLogin User Account Locked
rules.description: Detects when an user account is locked or suspended.

rules.name: OneLogin User Assumed Another User
rules.description: Detects when an user assumed another user account.

rules.name: Outdated Dependency Or Vulnerability Alert Disabled
rules.description:
Dependabot performs a scan to detect insecure dependencies, and sends Dependabot alerts.
This rule detects when an organization owner disables Dependabot alerts private repositories or Dependabot security updates for all repositories.

rules.name: Github Delete Action Invoked
rules.description: Detects delete action in the Github audit logs for codespaces, environment, project and repo.

rules.name: Github New Secret Created
rules.description: Detects when a user creates action secret for the organization, environment, codespaces or repository.

rules.name: New Github Organization Member Added
rules.description: Detects when a new member is added or invited to a github organization.

rules.name: Github Push Protection Disabled
rules.description: Detects if the push protection feature is disabled for an organization, enterprise, repositories or custom pattern rules.

rules.name: Github SSH Certificate Configuration Changed
rules.description: Detects when changes are made to the SSH certificate configuration of the organization.

rules.name: Github Push Protection Bypass Detected
rules.description: Detects when a user bypasses the push protection on a secret detected by secret scanning.

rules.name: Github Outside Collaborator Detected
rules.description: Detects when an organization member or an outside collaborator is added to or removed from a project board or has their permission level changed or when an owner removes an outside collaborator from an organization or when two-factor authentication is required in an organization and an outside collaborator does not use 2FA or disables 2FA.

rules.name: Github High Risk Configuration Disabled
rules.description: Detects when a user disables a critical security feature for an organization.

rules.name: Github Repository/Organization Transferred
rules.description: Detects when a repository or an organization is being transferred to another location.

rules.name: Github Fork Private Repositories Setting Enabled/Cleared
rules.description: Detects when the policy allowing forks of private and internal repositories is changed (enabled or cleared).

rules.name: Github Secret Scanning Feature Disabled
rules.description: Detects if the secret scanning feature is disabled for an enterprise or repository.

rules.name: Github Self Hosted Runner Changes Detected
rules.description:
A self-hosted runner is a system that you deploy and manage to execute jobs from GitHub Actions on GitHub.com.
This rule detects changes to self-hosted runners configurations in the environment. The self-hosted runner configuration changes once detected,
it should be validated from GitHub UI because the log entry may not provide full context.

rules.name: New Federated Domain Added - Exchange
rules.description: Detects the addition of a new Federated Domain.

rules.name: PST Export Alert Using eDiscovery Alert
rules.description: Alert on when a user has performed an eDiscovery search or exported a PST file from the search. This PST file usually has sensitive information including email body content

rules.name: PST Export Alert Using New-ComplianceSearchAction
rules.description: Alert when a user has performed an export to a search using 'New-ComplianceSearchAction' with the '-Export' flag. This detection will detect PST export even if the 'eDiscovery search or exported' alert is disabled in the O365.This rule will apply to ExchangePowerShell usage and from the cloud.

rules.name: Suspicious Inbox Forwarding
rules.description: Detects when a Microsoft Cloud App Security reported suspicious email forwarding rules, for example, if a user created an inbox rule that forwards a copy of all emails to an external address.

rules.name: Activity from Anonymous IP Addresses
rules.description: Detects when a Microsoft Cloud App Security reported when users were active from an IP address that has been identified as an anonymous proxy IP address.

rules.name: Activity Performed by Terminated User
rules.description:
Detects when a Microsoft Cloud App Security reported for users whose account were terminated in Azure AD, but still perform activities in other platforms such as AWS or Salesforce.
This is especially relevant for users who use another account to manage resources, since these accounts are often not terminated when a user leaves the company.

rules.name: Data Exfiltration to Unsanctioned Apps
rules.description: Detects when a Microsoft Cloud App Security reported when a user or IP address uses an app that is not sanctioned to perform an activity that resembles an attempt to exfiltrate information from your organization.

rules.name: Microsoft 365 - Unusual Volume of File Deletion
rules.description: Detects when a Microsoft Cloud App Security reported a user has deleted a unusual a large volume of files.

rules.name: Activity from Infrequent Country
rules.description: Detects when a Microsoft Cloud App Security reported when an activity occurs from a location that wasn't recently or never visited by any user in the organization.

rules.name: Suspicious OAuth App File Download Activities
rules.description: Detects when a Microsoft Cloud App Security reported when an app downloads multiple files from Microsoft SharePoint or Microsoft OneDrive in a manner that is unusual for the user.

rules.name: Logon from a Risky IP Address
rules.description: Detects when a Microsoft Cloud App Security reported when a user signs into your sanctioned apps from a risky IP address.

rules.name: Microsoft 365 - Potential Ransomware Activity
rules.description: Detects when a Microsoft Cloud App Security reported when a user uploads files to the cloud that might be infected with ransomware.

rules.name: Microsoft 365 - User Restricted from Sending Email
rules.description: Detects when a Security Compliance Center reported a user who exceeded sending limits of the service policies and because of this has been restricted from sending email.

rules.name: Microsoft 365 - Impossible Travel Activity
rules.description: Detects when a Microsoft Cloud App Security reported a risky sign-in attempt due to a login associated with an impossible travel.

rules.name: Activity from Suspicious IP Addresses
rules.description:
Detects when a Microsoft Cloud App Security reported users were active from an IP address identified as risky by Microsoft Threat Intelligence.
These IP addresses are involved in malicious activities, such as Botnet C&C, and may indicate compromised account.

rules.name: Disabling Multi Factor Authentication
rules.description: Detects disabling of Multi Factor Authentication.

rules.name: New Federated Domain Added
rules.description: Detects the addition of a new Federated Domain.

rules.name: Azure Login Bypassing Conditional Access Policies
rules.description: Detects a successful login to the Microsoft Intune Company Portal which could allow bypassing Conditional Access Policies and InTune device trust using a tool like TokenSmith.

rules.name: Okta Admin Functions Access Through Proxy
rules.description: Detects access to Okta admin functions through proxy.

rules.name: Okta Admin Role Assigned to an User or Group
rules.description: Detects when an the Administrator role is assigned to an user or group.

rules.name: Okta Unauthorized Access to App
rules.description: Detects when unauthorized access to app occurs.

rules.name: Okta Security Threat Detected
rules.description: Detects when an security threat is detected in Okta.

rules.name: Okta User Account Locked Out
rules.description: Detects when an user account is locked out.

rules.name: Okta MFA Reset or Deactivated
rules.description: Detects when an attempt at deactivating  or resetting MFA.

rules.name: Okta API Token Created
rules.description: Detects when a API token is created

rules.name: Okta Identity Provider Created
rules.description: Detects when a new identity provider is created for Okta.

rules.name: Okta Suspicious Activity Reported by End-user
rules.description: Detects when an Okta end-user reports activity by their account as being potentially suspicious.

rules.name: Okta Application Sign-On Policy Modified or Deleted
rules.description: Detects when an application Sign-on Policy is modified or deleted.

rules.name: Okta Network Zone Deactivated or Deleted
rules.description: Detects when an Network Zone is Deactivated or Deleted.

rules.name: Okta Policy Modified or Deleted
rules.description: Detects when an Okta policy is modified or deleted.

rules.name: Potential Okta Password in AlternateID Field
rules.description:
Detects when a user has potentially entered their password into the
username field, which will cause the password to be retained in log files.

rules.name: Okta Application Modified or Deleted
rules.description: Detects when an application is modified or deleted.

rules.name: Okta New Admin Console Behaviours
rules.description: Detects when Okta identifies new activity in the Admin Console.

rules.name: New Okta User Created
rules.description: Detects new user account creation

rules.name: Okta FastPass Phishing Detection
rules.description: Detects when Okta FastPass prevents a known phishing site.

rules.name: Okta Admin Role Assignment Created
rules.description: Detects when a new admin role assignment is created. Which could be a sign of privilege escalation or persistence

rules.name: Okta User Session Start Via An Anonymising Proxy Service
rules.description: Detects when an Okta user session starts where the user is behind an anonymising proxy service.

rules.name: Okta Policy Rule Modified or Deleted
rules.description: Detects when an Policy Rule is Modified or Deleted.

rules.name: Okta API Token Revoked
rules.description: Detects when a API Token is revoked.

rules.name: AWS EFS Fileshare Mount Modified or Deleted
rules.description: Detects when a EFS Fileshare Mount is modified or deleted. An adversary breaking any file system using the mount target that is being deleted, which might disrupt instances or applications using those mounts.

rules.name: AWS Identity Center Identity Provider Change
rules.description:
Detects a change in the AWS Identity Center (FKA AWS SSO) identity provider.
A change in identity provider allows an attacker to establish persistent access or escalate privileges via user impersonation.

rules.name: AWS Key Pair Import Activity
rules.description: Detects the import of SSH key pairs into AWS EC2, which may indicate an attacker attempting to gain unauthorized access to instances. This activity could lead to initial access, persistence, or privilege escalation, potentially compromising sensitive data and operations.

rules.name: AWS IAM S3Browser LoginProfile Creation
rules.description: Detects S3 Browser utility performing reconnaissance looking for existing IAM Users without a LoginProfile defined then (when found) creating a LoginProfile.

rules.name: AWS Console GetSigninToken Potential Abuse
rules.description:
Detects potentially suspicious events involving "GetSigninToken".
An adversary using the "aws_consoler" tool can leverage this console API to create temporary federated credential that help obfuscate which AWS credential is compromised (the original access key) and enables the adversary to pivot from the AWS CLI to console sessions without the need for MFA using the new access key issued in this request.

rules.name: Restore Public AWS RDS Instance
rules.description: Detects the recovery of a new public database instance from a snapshot. It may be a part of data exfiltration.

rules.name: Potential Malicious Usage of CloudTrail System Manager
rules.description: Detect when System Manager successfully executes commands against an instance.

rules.name: AWS User Login Profile Was Modified
rules.description:
Detects activity when someone is changing passwords on behalf of other users.
An attacker with the "iam:UpdateLoginProfile" permission on other users can change the password used to login to the AWS console on any user that already has a login profile setup.

rules.name: AWS CloudTrail Important Change
rules.description: Detects disabling, deleting and updating of a Trail

rules.name: Malicious Usage Of IMDS Credentials Outside Of AWS Infrastructure
rules.description:
Detects when an instance identity has taken an action that isn't inside SSM.
This can indicate that a compromised EC2 instance is being used as a pivot point.

rules.name: AWS Route 53 Domain Transferred to Another Account
rules.description: Detects when a request has been made to transfer a Route 53 domain to another AWS account.

rules.name: SES Identity Has Been Deleted
rules.description: Detects an instance of an SES identity being deleted via the "DeleteIdentity" event. This may be an indicator of an adversary removing the account that carried out suspicious or malicious activities

rules.name: New Network Route Added
rules.description: Detects the addition of a new network route to a route table in AWS.

rules.name: AWS Snapshot Backup Exfiltration
rules.description: Detects the modification of an EC2 snapshot's permissions to enable access from another account

rules.name: AWS SAML Provider Deletion Activity
rules.description:
Detects the deletion of an AWS SAML provider, potentially indicating malicious intent to disrupt administrative or security team access.
An attacker can remove the SAML provider for the information security team or a team of system administrators, to make it difficult for them to work and investigate at the time of the attack and after it.

rules.name: AWS EC2 VM Export Failure
rules.description: An attempt to export an AWS EC2 instance has been detected. A VM Export might indicate an attempt to extract information from an instance.

rules.name: Ingress/Egress Security Group Modification
rules.description:
Detects when an account makes changes to the ingress or egress rules of a security group.
This can indicate that an attacker is attempting to open up new attack vectors in the account, that they are trying to exfiltrate data over the network, or that they are trying to allow machines in that VPC/Subnet to contact a C&C server.

rules.name: New AWS Lambda Function URL Configuration Created
rules.description:
Detects when a user creates a Lambda function URL configuration, which could be used to expose the function to the internet and potentially allow unauthorized access to the function's IAM role for AWS API calls.
This could give an adversary access to the privileges associated with the Lambda service role that is attached to that function.

rules.name: AWS GuardDuty Important Change
rules.description: Detects updates of the GuardDuty list of trusted IPs, perhaps to disable security alerts against malicious IPs.

rules.name: AWS Glue Development Endpoint Activity
rules.description: Detects possible suspicious glue development endpoint activity.

rules.name: New Network ACL Entry Added
rules.description: Detects that network ACL entries have been added to a route table which could indicate that new attack vectors have been opened up in the AWS account.

rules.name: AWS IAM S3Browser Templated S3 Bucket Policy Creation
rules.description: Detects S3 browser utility creating Inline IAM policy containing default S3 bucket name placeholder value of "<YOUR-BUCKET-NAME>".

rules.name: AWS New Lambda Layer Attached
rules.description:
Detects when a user attached a Lambda layer to an existing Lambda function.
A malicious Lambda layer could execute arbitrary code in the context of the function's IAM role.
This would give an adversary access to resources that the function has access to.

rules.name: AWS EC2 Disable EBS Encryption
rules.description:
Identifies disabling of default Amazon Elastic Block Store (EBS) encryption in the current region.
Disabling default encryption does not change the encryption status of your existing volumes.

rules.name: LoadBalancer Security Group Modification
rules.description:
Detects changes to the security groups associated with an Elastic Load Balancer (ELB) or Application Load Balancer (ALB).
This can indicate that a misconfiguration allowing more traffic into the system than required, or could indicate that an attacker is attempting to enable new connections into a VPC or subnet controlled by the account.

rules.name: RDS Database Security Group Modification
rules.description:
Detects changes to the security group entries for RDS databases.
This can indicate that a misconfiguration has occurred which potentially exposes the database to the public internet, a wider audience within the VPC or that removal of valid rules has occurred which could impact the availability of the database to legitimate services and users.

rules.name: Potential Bucket Enumeration on AWS
rules.description: Looks for potential enumeration of AWS buckets via ListBuckets.

rules.name: AWS STS AssumeRole Misuse
rules.description: Identifies the suspicious use of AssumeRole. Attackers could move laterally and escalate privileges.

rules.name: AWS EC2 Startup Shell Script Change
rules.description: Detects changes to the EC2 instance startup script. The shell script will be executed as root/SYSTEM every time the specific instances are booted up.

rules.name: Modification or Deletion of an AWS RDS Cluster
rules.description: Detects modifications to an RDS cluster or its deletion, which may indicate potential data exfiltration attempts, unauthorized access, or exposure of sensitive information.

rules.name: AWS EKS Cluster Created or Deleted
rules.description: Identifies when an EKS cluster is created or deleted.

rules.name: AWS S3 Bucket Versioning Disable
rules.description: Detects when S3 bucket versioning is disabled. Threat actors use this technique during AWS ransomware incidents prior to deleting S3 objects.

rules.name: AWS STS GetSessionToken Misuse
rules.description: Identifies the suspicious use of GetSessionToken. Tokens could be created and used by attackers to move laterally and escalate privileges.

rules.name: AWS ECS Task Definition That Queries The Credential Endpoint
rules.description:
Detects when an Elastic Container Service (ECS) Task Definition includes a command to query the credential endpoint.
This can indicate a potential adversary adding a backdoor to establish persistence or escalate privileges.

rules.name: AWS EFS Fileshare Modified or Deleted
rules.description:
Detects when a EFS Fileshare is modified or deleted.
You can't delete a file system that is in use.
If the file system has any mount targets, the adversary must first delete them, so deletion of a mount will occur before deletion of a fileshare.

rules.name: AWS S3 Data Management Tampering
rules.description: Detects when a user tampers with S3 data management in Amazon Web Services.

rules.name: AWS Root Credentials
rules.description: Detects AWS root account usage

rules.name: AWS IAM Backdoor Users Keys
rules.description:
Detects AWS API key creation for a user by another user.
Backdoored users can be used to obtain persistence in the AWS environment.
Also with this alert, you can detect a flow of AWS keys in your org.

rules.name: AWS RDS Master Password Change
rules.description: Detects the change of database master password. It may be a part of data exfiltration.

rules.name: AWS SecurityHub Findings Evasion
rules.description: Detects the modification of the findings on SecurityHub.

rules.name: AWS Config Disabling Channel/Recorder
rules.description: Detects AWS Config Service disabling

rules.name: AWS Suspicious SAML Activity
rules.description: Identifies when suspicious SAML activity has occurred in AWS. An adversary could gain backdoor access via SAML.

rules.name: AWS Route 53 Domain Transfer Lock Disabled
rules.description: Detects when a transfer lock was removed from a Route 53 domain. It is recommended to refrain from performing this action unless intending to transfer the domain to a different registrar.

rules.name: AWS ElastiCache Security Group Modified or Deleted
rules.description: Identifies when an ElastiCache security group has been modified or deleted.

rules.name: AWS ElastiCache Security Group Created
rules.description: Detects when an ElastiCache security group has been created.

rules.name: AWS IAM S3Browser User or AccessKey Creation
rules.description: Detects S3 Browser utility creating IAM User or AccessKey.

rules.name: Bitbucket Project Secret Scanning Allowlist Added
rules.description: Detects when a secret scanning allowlist rule is added for projects.

rules.name: Bitbucket Unauthorized Full Data Export Triggered
rules.description: Detects when full data export is attempted an unauthorized user.

rules.name: Bitbucket Full Data Export Triggered
rules.description: Detects when full data export is attempted.

rules.name: Bitbucket User Permissions Export Attempt
rules.description: Detects user permission data export attempt.

rules.name: Bitbucket Unauthorized Access To A Resource
rules.description: Detects unauthorized access attempts to a resource.

rules.name: Bitbucket Global SSH Settings Changed
rules.description: Detects Bitbucket global SSH access configuration changes.

rules.name: Bitbucket User Details Export Attempt Detected
rules.description: Detects user data export activity.

rules.name: Bitbucket Secret Scanning Rule Deleted
rules.description: Detects when secret scanning rule is deleted for the project or repository.

rules.name: Bitbucket Global Secret Scanning Rule Deleted
rules.description: Detects Bitbucket global secret scanning rule deletion activity.

rules.name: Bitbucket Audit Log Configuration Updated
rules.description: Detects changes to the bitbucket audit log configuration.

rules.name: Bitbucket User Login Failure
rules.description:
Detects user authentication failure events.
Please note that this rule can be noisy and it is recommended to use with correlation based on "author.name" field.

rules.name: Bitbucket Global Permission Changed
rules.description: Detects global permissions change activity.

rules.name: Bitbucket Secret Scanning Exempt Repository Added
rules.description: Detects when a repository is exempted from secret scanning feature.

rules.name: Bitbucket User Login Failure Via SSH
rules.description:
Detects SSH user login access failures.
Please note that this rule can be noisy and is recommended to use with correlation based on "author.name" field.

rules.name: SharpHound Recon Account Discovery
rules.description: Detects remote RPC calls useb by SharpHound to map remote connections and local group membership.

rules.name: Remote Event Log Recon
rules.description: Detects remote RPC calls to get event log information via EVEN or EVEN6

rules.name: Remote Printing Abuse for Lateral Movement
rules.description: Detects remote RPC calls to possibly abuse remote printing service via MS-RPRN / MS-PAR

rules.name: Remote Encrypting File System Abuse
rules.description: Detects remote RPC calls to possibly abuse remote encryption service via MS-EFSR

rules.name: Remote Schedule Task Recon via ITaskSchedulerService
rules.description: Detects remote RPC calls to read information about scheduled tasks

rules.name: Remote Schedule Task Recon via AtScv
rules.description: Detects remote RPC calls to read information about scheduled tasks via AtScv

rules.name: Remote Registry Recon
rules.description: Detects remote RPC calls to collect information

rules.name: Remote Server Service Abuse for Lateral Movement
rules.description: Detects remote RPC calls to possibly abuse remote encryption service via MS-EFSR

rules.name: Remote Registry Lateral Movement
rules.description: Detects remote RPC calls to modify the registry and possible execute code

rules.name: Remote Schedule Task Lateral Movement via ATSvc
rules.description: Detects remote RPC calls to create or execute a scheduled task via ATSvc

rules.name: Remote Schedule Task Lateral Movement via ITaskSchedulerService
rules.description: Detects remote RPC calls to create or execute a scheduled task

rules.name: Possible DCSync Attack
rules.description: Detects remote RPC calls to MS-DRSR from non DC hosts, which could indicate DCSync / DCShadow attacks.

rules.name: Remote Server Service Abuse
rules.description: Detects remote RPC calls to possibly abuse remote encryption service via MS-SRVS

rules.name: SharpHound Recon Sessions
rules.description: Detects remote RPC calls useb by SharpHound to map remote connections and local group membership.

rules.name: Recon Activity via SASec
rules.description: Detects remote RPC calls to read information about scheduled tasks via SASec

rules.name: Remote Schedule Task Lateral Movement via SASec
rules.description: Detects remote RPC calls to create or execute a scheduled task via SASec

rules.name: Remote DCOM/WMI Lateral Movement
rules.description: Detects remote RPC calls that performs remote DCOM operations. These could be abused for lateral movement via DCOM or WMI.

rules.name: Potential RCE Exploitation Attempt In NodeJS
rules.description: Detects process execution related errors in NodeJS. If the exceptions are caused due to user input then they may suggest an RCE vulnerability.

rules.name: Python SQL Exceptions
rules.description: Generic rule for SQL exceptions in Python according to PEP 249

rules.name: Potential XXE Exploitation Attempt In JVM Based Application
rules.description: Detects XML parsing issues, if the application expects to work with XML make sure that the parser is initialized safely.

rules.name: Process Execution Error In JVM Based Application
rules.description: Detects process execution related exceptions in JVM based apps, often relates to RCE

rules.name: Potential Local File Read Vulnerability In JVM Based Application
rules.description:
Detects potential local file read vulnerability in JVM based apps.
If the exceptions are caused due to user input and contain path traversal payloads then it's a red flag.

rules.name: Potential JNDI Injection Exploitation In JVM Based Application
rules.description: Detects potential JNDI Injection exploitation. Often coupled with Log4Shell exploitation.

rules.name: Potential OGNL Injection Exploitation In JVM Based Application
rules.description:
Detects potential OGNL Injection exploitation, which may lead to RCE.
OGNL is an expression language that is supported in many JVM based systems.
OGNL Injection is the reason for some high profile RCE's such as Apache Struts (CVE-2017-5638) and Confluence (CVE-2022-26134)

rules.name: Potential Server Side Template Injection In Velocity
rules.description: Detects exceptions in velocity template renderer, this most likely happens due to dynamic rendering of user input and may lead to RCE.

rules.name: Kubernetes CronJob/Job Modification
rules.description:
Detects when a Kubernetes CronJob or Job is created or modified.
A Kubernetes Job creates one or more pods to accomplish a specific task, and a CronJob creates Jobs on a recurring schedule.
An adversary can take advantage of this Kubernetes object to schedule Jobs to run containers that execute malicious code within a cluster, allowing them to achieve persistence.

rules.name: Potential Sidecar Injection Into Running Deployment
rules.description:
Detects attempts to inject a sidecar container into a running deployment.
A sidecar container is an additional container within a pod, that resides alongside the main container.
One way to add containers to running resources like Deployments/DeamonSets/StatefulSets, is via a "kubectl patch" operation.
By injecting a new container within a legitimate pod, an attacker can run their code and hide their activity, instead of running their own separated pod in the cluster.

rules.name: Kubernetes Secrets Enumeration
rules.description: Detects enumeration of Kubernetes secrets.

rules.name: Container With A hostPath Mount Created
rules.description:
Detects creation of a container with a hostPath mount.
A hostPath volume mounts a directory or a file from the node to the container.
Attackers who have permissions to create a new pod in the cluster may create one with a writable hostPath volume and chroot to escape to the underlying node.

rules.name: Privileged Container Deployed
rules.description:
Detects the creation of a "privileged" container, an action which could be indicative of a threat actor mounting a container breakout attacks.
A privileged container is a container that can access the host with all of the root capabilities of the host machine. This allows it to view, interact and modify processes, network operations, IPC calls, the file system, mount points, SELinux configurations etc. as the root user on the host.
Various versions of "privileged" containers can be specified, e.g. by setting the securityContext.privileged flag in the resource specification, setting non-standard Linux capabilities, or configuring the hostNetwork/hostPID fields

rules.name: Potential Remote Command Execution In Pod Container
rules.description: Detects attempts to execute remote commands, within a Pod's container using e.g. the "kubectl exec" command.

rules.name: Kubernetes Events Deleted
rules.description:
Detects when events are deleted in Kubernetes.
An adversary may delete Kubernetes events in an attempt to evade detection.

rules.name: Creation Of Pod In System Namespace
rules.description:
Detects deployments of pods within the kube-system namespace, which could be intended to imitate system pods.
System pods, created by controllers such as Deployments or DaemonSets have random suffixes in their names.
Attackers can use this fact and name their backdoor pods as if they were created by these controllers to avoid detection.
Deployment of such a backdoor container e.g. named kube-proxy-bv61v, could be attempted in the kube-system namespace alongside the other administrative containers.

rules.name: Kubernetes Rolebinding Modification
rules.description: Detects when a Kubernetes Rolebinding is created or modified.

rules.name: RBAC Permission Enumeration Attempt
rules.description:
Detects identities attempting to enumerate their Kubernetes RBAC permissions.
In the early stages of a breach, attackers will aim to list the permissions they have within the compromised environment.
In a Kubernetes cluster, this can be achieved by interacting with the API server, and querying the SelfSubjectAccessReview API via e.g. a "kubectl auth can-i --list" command.
This will enumerate the Role-Based Access Controls (RBAC) rules defining the compromised user's authorization.

rules.name: Kubernetes Secrets Modified or Deleted
rules.description: Detects when Kubernetes Secrets are Modified or Deleted.

rules.name: Kubernetes Admission Controller Modification
rules.description: Detects when a modification (create, update or replace) action is taken that affects mutating or validating webhook configurations, as they can be used by an adversary to achieve persistence or exfiltrate access credentials.

rules.name: Kubernetes Unauthorized or Unauthenticated Access
rules.description:
Detects when a request to the Kubernetes API is rejected due to lack of authorization or due to an expired authentication token being used.
This may indicate an attacker attempting to leverage credentials they have obtained.

rules.name: New Kubernetes Service Account Created
rules.description: Detects creation of new Kubernetes service account, which could indicate an attacker's attempt to persist within a cluster.

rules.name: Deployment Deleted From Kubernetes Cluster
rules.description:
Detects the removal of a deployment from a Kubernetes cluster.
This could indicate disruptive activity aiming to impact business operations.

rules.name: Django Framework Exceptions
rules.description: Detects suspicious Django web application framework exceptions that could indicate exploitation attempts

rules.name: Ruby on Rails Framework Exceptions
rules.description: Detects suspicious Ruby on Rails exceptions that could indicate exploitation attempts

rules.name: Potential SpEL Injection In Spring Framework
rules.description: Detects potential SpEL Injection exploitation, which may lead to RCE.

rules.name: Spring Framework Exceptions
rules.description: Detects suspicious Spring framework exceptions that could indicate exploitation attempts

rules.name: OpenCanary - SMB File Open Request
rules.description: Detects instances where an SMB service on an OpenCanary node has had a file open request.

rules.name: OpenCanary - REDIS Action Command Attempt
rules.description: Detects instances where a REDIS service on an OpenCanary node has had an action command attempted.

rules.name: OpenCanary - GIT Clone Request
rules.description: Detects instances where a GIT service on an OpenCanary node has had Git Clone request.

rules.name: OpenCanary - SSH Login Attempt
rules.description: Detects instances where an SSH service on an OpenCanary node has had a login attempt.

rules.name: OpenCanary - HTTP GET Request
rules.description: Detects instances where an HTTP service on an OpenCanary node has received a GET request.

rules.name: OpenCanary - SIP Request
rules.description: Detects instances where an SIP service on an OpenCanary node has had a SIP request.

rules.name: OpenCanary - NTP Monlist Request
rules.description: Detects instances where an NTP service on an OpenCanary node has had a NTP monlist request.

rules.name: OpenCanary - SNMP OID Request
rules.description: Detects instances where an SNMP service on an OpenCanary node has had an OID request.

rules.name: OpenCanary - HTTPPROXY Login Attempt
rules.description: Detects instances where an HTTPPROXY service on an OpenCanary node has had an attempt to proxy another page.

rules.name: OpenCanary - MSSQL Login Attempt Via Windows Authentication
rules.description: Detects instances where an MSSQL service on an OpenCanary node has had a login attempt using Windows Authentication.

rules.name: OpenCanary - VNC Connection Attempt
rules.description: Detects instances where a VNC service on an OpenCanary node has had a connection attempt.

rules.name: OpenCanary - HTTP POST Login Attempt
rules.description: Detects instances where an HTTP service on an OpenCanary node has had login attempt via Form POST.

rules.name: OpenCanary - Telnet Login Attempt
rules.description: Detects instances where a Telnet service on an OpenCanary node has had a login attempt.

rules.name: OpenCanary - FTP Login Attempt
rules.description: Detects instances where an FTP service on an OpenCanary node has had a login attempt.

rules.name: OpenCanary - MySQL Login Attempt
rules.description: Detects instances where a MySQL service on an OpenCanary node has had a login attempt.

rules.name: OpenCanary - SSH New Connection Attempt
rules.description: Detects instances where an SSH service on an OpenCanary node has had a connection attempt.

rules.name: OpenCanary - TFTP Request
rules.description: Detects instances where a TFTP service on an OpenCanary node has had a request.

rules.name: OpenCanary - MSSQL Login Attempt Via SQLAuth
rules.description: Detects instances where an MSSQL service on an OpenCanary node has had a login attempt using SQLAuth.

rules.name: Suspicious SQL Error Messages
rules.description: Detects SQL error messages that indicate probing for an injection attack

rules.name: HackTool - EfsPotato Named Pipe Creation
rules.description: Detects the pattern of a pipe name as used by the hack tool EfsPotato

rules.name: HackTool - Koh Default Named Pipe
rules.description: Detects creation of default named pipes used by the Koh tool

rules.name: PsExec Tool Execution From Suspicious Locations - PipeName
rules.description: Detects PsExec default pipe creation where the image executed is located in a suspicious location. Which could indicate that the tool is being used in an attack

rules.name: PUA - PAExec Default Named Pipe
rules.description: Detects PAExec default named pipe

rules.name: HackTool - Credential Dumping Tools Named Pipe Created
rules.description: Detects well-known credential dumping tools execution via specific named pipe creation

rules.name: Alternate PowerShell Hosts Pipe
rules.description: Detects alternate PowerShell hosts potentially bypassing detections looking for powershell.exe

rules.name: HackTool - DiagTrackEoP Default Named Pipe
rules.description: Detects creation of default named pipe used by the DiagTrackEoP POC, a tool that abuses "SeImpersonate" privilege.

rules.name: PUA - RemCom Default Named Pipe
rules.description: Detects default RemCom pipe creation

rules.name: CobaltStrike Named Pipe Pattern Regex
rules.description: Detects the creation of a named pipe matching a pattern used by CobaltStrike Malleable C2 profiles

rules.name: New PowerShell Instance Created
rules.description: Detects the execution of PowerShell via the creation of a named pipe starting with PSHost

rules.name: CobaltStrike Named Pipe Patterns
rules.description: Detects the creation of a named pipe with a pattern found in CobaltStrike malleable C2 profiles

rules.name: CobaltStrike Named Pipe
rules.description: Detects the creation of a named pipe as used by CobaltStrike

rules.name: PUA - CSExec Default Named Pipe
rules.description: Detects default CSExec pipe creation

rules.name: WMI Event Consumer Created Named Pipe
rules.description: Detects the WMI Event Consumer service scrcons.exe creating a named pipe

rules.name: HackTool - CoercedPotato Named Pipe Creation
rules.description: Detects the pattern of a pipe name as used by the hack tool CoercedPotato

rules.name: Malicious Named Pipe Created
rules.description: Detects the creation of a named pipe seen used by known APTs or malware.

rules.name: ADFS Database Named Pipe Connection By Uncommon Tool
rules.description:
Detects suspicious local connections via a named pipe to the AD FS configuration database (Windows Internal Database).
Used to access information such as the AD FS configuration settings which contains sensitive information used to sign SAML tokens.

rules.name: Potential Process Hollowing Activity
rules.description: Detects when a memory process image does not match the disk image, indicative of process hollowing.

rules.name: Suspicious Appended Extension
rules.description: Detects file renames where the target filename uses an uncommon double extension. Could indicate potential ransomware activity renaming files and adding a custom extension to the encrypted files, such as ".jpg.crypted", ".docx.locky", etc.

rules.name: Potentially Suspicious Self Extraction Directive File Created
rules.description:
Detects the creation of a binary file with the ".sed" extension. The ".sed" extension stand for Self Extraction Directive files.
These files are used by the "iexpress.exe" utility in order to create self extracting packages.
Attackers were seen abusing this utility and creating PE files with embedded ".sed" entries.
Usually ".sed" files are simple ini files and not PE binaries.

rules.name: Suspicious File Created Via OneNote Application
rules.description: Detects suspicious files created via the OneNote application. This could indicate a potential malicious ".one"/".onepkg" file was executed as seen being used in malware activity in the wild

rules.name: Created Files by Microsoft Sync Center
rules.description: This rule detects suspicious files created by Microsoft Sync Center (mobsync)

rules.name: Visual Studio Code Tunnel Remote File Creation
rules.description: Detects the creation of file by the "node.exe" process in the ".vscode-server" directory. Could be a sign of remote file creation via VsCode tunnel feature

rules.name: Writing Local Admin Share
rules.description:
Aversaries may use to interact with a remote network share using Server Message Block (SMB).
This technique is used by post-exploitation frameworks.

rules.name: Suspicious MSExchangeMailboxReplication ASPX Write
rules.description: Detects suspicious activity in which the MSExchangeMailboxReplication process writes .asp and .apsx files to disk, which could be a sign of ProxyShell exploitation

rules.name: Suspicious File Creation Activity From Fake Recycle.Bin Folder
rules.description: Detects file write event from/to a fake recycle bin folder that is often used as a staging directory for malware

rules.name: UAC Bypass Using Windows Media Player - File
rules.description: Detects the pattern of UAC Bypass using Windows Media Player osksupport.dll (UACMe 32)

rules.name: Potential Persistence Attempt Via ErrorHandler.Cmd
rules.description:
Detects creation of a file named "ErrorHandler.cmd" in the "C:\WINDOWS\Setup\Scripts\" directory which could be used as a method of persistence
The content of C:\WINDOWS\Setup\Scripts\ErrorHandler.cmd is read whenever some tools under C:\WINDOWS\System32\oobe\ (e.g. Setup.exe) fail to run for any reason.

rules.name: Suspicious Desktopimgdownldr Target File
rules.description: Detects a suspicious Microsoft desktopimgdownldr file creation that stores a file to a suspicious location or contains a file with a suspicious extension

rules.name: Suspicious Scheduled Task Write to System32 Tasks
rules.description: Detects the creation of tasks from processes executed from suspicious locations

rules.name: Process Monitor Driver Creation By Non-Sysinternals Binary
rules.description: Detects creation of the Process Monitor driver by processes other than Process Monitor (procmon) itself.

rules.name: Potential RipZip Attack on Startup Folder
rules.description:
Detects a phishing attack which expands a ZIP file containing a malicious shortcut.
If the victim expands the ZIP file via the explorer process, then the explorer process expands the malicious ZIP file and drops a malicious shortcut redirected to a backdoor into the Startup folder.
Additionally, the file name of the malicious shortcut in Startup folder contains {0AFACED1-E828-11D1-9187-B532F1E9575D} meaning the folder shortcut operation.

rules.name: UAC Bypass Using IEInstal - File
rules.description: Detects the pattern of UAC Bypass using IEInstal.exe (UACMe 64)

rules.name: PSEXEC Remote Execution File Artefact
rules.description: Detects creation of the PSEXEC key file. Which is created anytime a PsExec command is executed. It gets written to the file system and will be recorded in the USN Journal on the target system

rules.name: LiveKD Kernel Memory Dump File Created
rules.description: Detects the creation of a file that has the same name as the default LiveKD kernel memory dump.

rules.name: Files With System DLL Name In Unsuspected Locations
rules.description:
Detects the creation of a file with the ".dll" extension that has the name of a System DLL in uncommon or unsuspected locations. (Outisde of "System32", "SysWOW64", etc.).
It is highly recommended to perform an initial baseline before using this rule in production.

rules.name: UAC Bypass Using EventVwr
rules.description: Detects the pattern of a UAC bypass using Windows Event Viewer

rules.name: Suspicious PFX File Creation
rules.description: A general detection for processes creating PFX files. This could be an indicator of an adversary exporting a local certificate to a PFX file.

rules.name: EVTX Created In Uncommon Location
rules.description:
Detects the creation of new files with the ".evtx" extension in non-common or non-standard location.
This could indicate tampering with default EVTX locations in order to evade security controls or simply exfiltration of event log to search for sensitive information within.
Note that backup software and legitimate administrator might perform similar actions during troubleshooting.

rules.name: LSASS Process Dump Artefact In CrashDumps Folder
rules.description: Detects the presence of an LSASS dump file in the "CrashDumps" folder. This could be a sign of LSASS credential dumping. Techniques such as the LSASS Shtinkering have been seen abusing the Windows Error Reporting to dump said process.

rules.name: Windows Terminal Profile Settings Modification By Uncommon Process
rules.description: Detects the creation or modification of the Windows Terminal Profile settings file "settings.json" by an uncommon process.

rules.name: Potential Homoglyph Attack Using Lookalike Characters in Filename
rules.description:
Detects the presence of unicode characters which are homoglyphs, or identical in appearance, to ASCII letter characters.
This is used as an obfuscation and masquerading techniques. Only "perfect" homoglyphs are included; these are characters that
are indistinguishable from ASCII characters and thus may make excellent candidates for homoglyph attack characters.

rules.name: Potential Webshell Creation On Static Website
rules.description: Detects the creation of files with certain extensions on a static web site. This can be indicative of potential uploads of a web shell.

rules.name: Potential Persistence Via Notepad++ Plugins
rules.description: Detects creation of new ".dll" files inside the plugins directory of a notepad++ installation by a process other than "gup.exe". Which could indicates possible persistence

rules.name: Legitimate Application Dropped Executable
rules.description: Detects programs on a Windows system that should not write executables to disk

rules.name: Suspicious Binaries and Scripts in Public Folder
rules.description: Detects the creation of a file with a suspicious extension in the public folder, which could indicate potential malicious activity.

rules.name: Suspicious PROCEXP152.sys File Created In TMP
rules.description:
Detects the creation of the PROCEXP152.sys file in the application-data local temporary folder.
This driver is used by Sysinternals Process Explorer but also by KDU (https://github.com/hfiref0x/KDU) or Ghost-In-The-Logs (https://github.com/bats3c/Ghost-In-The-Logs), which uses KDU.

rules.name: Rclone Config File Creation
rules.description: Detects Rclone config files being created

rules.name: Suspicious Startup Folder Persistence
rules.description: Detects when a file with a suspicious extension is created in the startup folder

rules.name: Uncommon File Created In Office Startup Folder
rules.description: Detects the creation of a file with an uncommon extension in an Office application startup folder

rules.name: HackTool - Powerup Write Hijack DLL
rules.description:
Powerup tool's Write Hijack DLL exploits DLL hijacking for privilege escalation.
In it's default mode, it builds a self deleting .bat file which executes malicious command.
The detection rule relies on creation of the malicious bat file (debug.bat by default).

rules.name: File With Uncommon Extension Created By An Office Application
rules.description: Detects the creation of files with an executable or script extension by an Office application.

rules.name: LSASS Process Memory Dump Creation Via Taskmgr.EXE
rules.description: Detects the creation of an "lsass.dmp" file by the taskmgr process. This indicates a manual dumping of the LSASS.exe process memory using Windows Task Manager.

rules.name: Potential DCOM InternetExplorer.Application DLL Hijack
rules.description: Detects potential DLL hijack of "iertutil.dll" found in the DCOM InternetExplorer.Application Class over the network

rules.name: Potential Binary Or Script Dropper Via PowerShell
rules.description: Detects PowerShell creating a binary executable or a script file.

rules.name: WinSxS Executable File Creation By Non-System Process
rules.description: Detects the creation of binaries in the WinSxS folder by non-system processes

rules.name: Cred Dump Tools Dropped Files
rules.description: Files with well-known filenames (parts of credential dump software or files produced by them) creation

rules.name: Legitimate Application Dropped Archive
rules.description: Detects programs on a Windows system that should not write an archive to disk

rules.name: Suspicious Binary Writes Via AnyDesk
rules.description:
Detects AnyDesk writing binary files to disk other than "gcapi.dll".
According to RedCanary research it is highly abnormal for AnyDesk to write executable files to disk besides gcapi.dll,
which is a legitimate DLL that is part of the Google Chrome web browser used to interact with the Google Cloud API. (See reference section for more details)

rules.name: Suspicious Executable File Creation
rules.description:
Detect creation of suspicious executable file names.
Some strings look for suspicious file extensions, others look for filenames that exploit unquoted service paths.

rules.name: Creation of a Diagcab
rules.description: Detects the creation of diagcab file, which could be caused by some legitimate installer or is a sign of exploitation (review the filename and its location)

rules.name: UAC Bypass Using .NET Code Profiler on MMC
rules.description: Detects the pattern of UAC Bypass using .NET Code Profiler and mmc.exe DLL hijacking (UACMe 39)

rules.name: Suspicious File Creation In Uncommon AppData Folder
rules.description: Detects the creation of suspicious files and folders inside the user's AppData folder but not inside any of the common and well known directories (Local, Romaing, LocalLow). This method could be used as a method to bypass detection who exclude the AppData folder in fear of FPs

rules.name: NTDS Exfiltration Filename Patterns
rules.description: Detects creation of files with specific name patterns seen used in various tools that export the NTDS.DIT for exfiltration.

rules.name: Dynamic CSharp Compile Artefact
rules.description:
When C# is compiled dynamically, a .cmdline file will be created as a part of the process.
Certain processes are not typically observed compiling C# code, but can do so without touching disk.
This can be used to unpack a payload for execution

rules.name: WMI Persistence - Script Event Consumer File Write
rules.description: Detects file writes of WMI script event consumer

rules.name: Potentially Suspicious DMP/HDMP File Creation
rules.description: Detects the creation of a file with the ".dmp"/".hdmp" extension by a shell or scripting application such as "cmd", "powershell", etc. Often created by software during a crash. Memory dumps can sometimes contain sensitive information such as credentials. It's best to determine the source of the crash.

rules.name: HackTool - NPPSpy Hacktool Usage
rules.description: Detects the use of NPPSpy hacktool that stores cleartext passwords of users that logged in to a local file

rules.name: ADSI-Cache File Creation By Uncommon Tool
rules.description: Detects the creation of an "Active Directory Schema Cache File" (.sch) file by an uncommon tool.

rules.name: Malicious PowerShell Scripts - FileCreation
rules.description: Detects the creation of known offensive powershell scripts used for exploitation

rules.name: Office Macro File Download
rules.description: Detects the creation of a new office macro files on the systems via an application (browser, mail client).

rules.name: ISO File Created Within Temp Folders
rules.description: Detects the creation of a ISO file in the Outlook temp folder or in the Appdata temp folder. Typical of Qakbot TTP from end-July 2022.

rules.name: ScreenConnect Temporary Installation Artefact
rules.description:
An adversary may use legitimate desktop support and remote access software, such as Team Viewer, Go2Assist, LogMein, AmmyyAdmin, etc, to establish an interactive command and control channel to target systems within networks.
These services are commonly used as legitimate technical support software, and may be allowed by application control within a target environment.
Remote access tools like VNC, Ammyy, and Teamviewer are used frequently when compared with other legitimate software commonly used by adversaries. (Citation: Symantec Living off the Land)

rules.name: Legitimate Application Dropped Script
rules.description: Detects programs on a Windows system that should not write scripts to disk

rules.name: Potential Persistence Via Microsoft Office Add-In
rules.description: Detects potential persistence activity via startup add-ins that load when Microsoft Office starts (.wll/.xll are simply .dll fit for Word or Excel).

rules.name: Malicious DLL File Dropped in the Teams or OneDrive Folder
rules.description:
Detects creation of a malicious DLL file in the location where the OneDrive or Team applications
Upon execution of the Teams or OneDrive application, the dropped malicious DLL file ("iphlpapi.dll") is sideloaded

rules.name: New Custom Shim Database Created
rules.description:
Adversaries may establish persistence and/or elevate privileges by executing malicious content triggered by application shims.
The Microsoft Windows Application Compatibility Infrastructure/Framework (Application Shim) was created to allow for backward compatibility of software as the operating system codebase changes over time.

rules.name: PDF File Created By RegEdit.EXE
rules.description:
Detects the creation of a file with the ".pdf" extension by the "RegEdit.exe" process.
This indicates that a user is trying to print/save a registry key as a PDF in order to potentially extract sensitive information and bypass defenses.

rules.name: Creation Exe for Service with Unquoted Path
rules.description:
Adversaries may execute their own malicious payloads by hijacking vulnerable file path references.
Adversaries can take advantage of paths that lack surrounding quotations by placing an executable in a higher level directory within the path, so that Windows will choose the adversary's executable to launch.

rules.name: HackTool - QuarksPwDump Dump File
rules.description: Detects a dump file written by QuarksPwDump password dumper

rules.name: Potential Privilege Escalation Attempt Via .Exe.Local Technique
rules.description: Detects potential privilege escalation attempt via the creation of the "*.Exe.Local" folder inside the "System32" directory in order to sideload "comctl32.dll"

rules.name: PowerShell Module File Created By Non-PowerShell Process
rules.description: Detects the creation of a new PowerShell module ".psm1", ".psd1", ".dll", ".ps1", etc. by a non-PowerShell process

rules.name: ISO or Image Mount Indicator in Recent Files
rules.description:
Detects the creation of recent element file that points to an .ISO, .IMG, .VHD or .VHDX file as often used in phishing attacks.
This can be a false positive on server systems but on workstations users should rarely mount .iso or .img files.

rules.name: Suspicious Double Extension Files
rules.description: Detects dropped files with double extensions, which is often used by malware as a method to abuse the fact that Windows hide default extensions by default.

rules.name: PowerShell Script Dropped Via PowerShell.EXE
rules.description: Detects PowerShell creating a PowerShell file (.ps1). While often times this behavior is benign, sometimes it can be a sign of a dropper script trying to achieve persistence.

rules.name: Potential Persistence Via Microsoft Office Startup Folder
rules.description: Detects creation of Microsoft Office files inside of one of the default startup folders in order to achieve persistence.

rules.name: Suspicious LNK Double Extension File Created
rules.description: Detects the creation of files with an "LNK" as a second extension. This is sometimes used by malware as a method to abuse the fact that Windows hides the "LNK" extension by default.

rules.name: TeamViewer Remote Session
rules.description: Detects the creation of log files during a TeamViewer remote session

rules.name: UAC Bypass Using Consent and Comctl32 - File
rules.description: Detects the pattern of UAC Bypass using consent.exe and comctl32.dll (UACMe 22)

rules.name: Suspicious ASPX File Drop by Exchange
rules.description: Detects suspicious file type dropped by an Exchange component in IIS into a suspicious folder

rules.name: UAC Bypass Using NTFS Reparse Point - File
rules.description: Detects the pattern of UAC Bypass using NTFS reparse point and wusa.exe DLL hijacking (UACMe 36)

rules.name: HackTool - Typical HiveNightmare SAM File Export
rules.description: Detects files written by the different tools that exploit HiveNightmare

rules.name: Potential Hidden Directory Creation Via NTFS INDEX_ALLOCATION Stream
rules.description: Detects the creation of hidden file/folder with the "::$index_allocation" stream. Which can be used as a technique to prevent access to folder and files from tooling such as "explorer.exe" and "powershell.exe"

rules.name: Suspicious Files in Default GPO Folder
rules.description: Detects the creation of copy of suspicious files (EXE/DLL) to the default GPO storage folder

rules.name: Self Extraction Directive File Created In Potentially Suspicious Location
rules.description:
Detects the creation of Self Extraction Directive files (.sed) in a potentially suspicious location.
These files are used by the "iexpress.exe" utility in order to create self extracting packages.
Attackers were seen abusing this utility and creating PE files with embedded ".sed" entries.

rules.name: NTDS.DIT Creation By Uncommon Process
rules.description: Detects creation of a file named "ntds.dit" (Active Directory Database) by an uncommon process or a process located in a suspicious directory

rules.name: Potential SAM Database Dump
rules.description: Detects the creation of files that look like exports of the local SAM (Security Account Manager)

rules.name: VsCode Powershell Profile Modification
rules.description: Detects the creation or modification of a vscode related powershell profile which could indicate suspicious activity as the profile can be used as a mean of persistence

rules.name: Office Macro File Creation From Suspicious Process
rules.description: Detects the creation of a office macro file from a a suspicious process

rules.name: Startup Folder File Write
rules.description: A General detection for files being created in the Windows startup directory. This could be an indicator of persistence.

rules.name: LSASS Process Memory Dump Files
rules.description: Detects creation of files with names used by different memory dumping tools to create a memory dump of the LSASS process memory, which contains user credentials.

rules.name: Potential Winnti Dropper Activity
rules.description: Detects files dropped by Winnti as described in RedMimicry Winnti playbook

rules.name: UAC Bypass Abusing Winsat Path Parsing - File
rules.description: Detects the pattern of UAC Bypass using a path parsing issue in winsat.exe (UACMe 52)

rules.name: HackTool - Inveigh Execution Artefacts
rules.description: Detects the presence and execution of Inveigh via dropped artefacts

rules.name: Assembly DLL Creation Via AspNetCompiler
rules.description: Detects the creation of new DLL assembly files by "aspnet_compiler.exe", which could be a sign of "aspnet_compiler" abuse to proxy execution through a build provider.

rules.name: HackTool - RemoteKrbRelay SMB Relay Secrets Dump Module Indicators
rules.description: Detects the creation of file with specific names used by RemoteKrbRelay SMB Relay attack module.

rules.name: Files With System Process Name In Unsuspected Locations
rules.description:
Detects the creation of an executable with a system process name in folders other than the system ones (System32, SysWOW64, etc.).
It is highly recommended to perform an initial baseline before using this rule in production.

rules.name: Advanced IP Scanner - File Event
rules.description: Detects the use of Advanced IP Scanner. Seems to be a popular tool for ransomware groups.

rules.name: Octopus Scanner Malware
rules.description: Detects Octopus Scanner Malware.

rules.name: LiveKD Driver Creation By Uncommon Process
rules.description: Detects the creation of the LiveKD driver by a process image other than "livekd.exe".

rules.name: Creation Of Non-Existent System DLL
