rules.description:
Detects the creation of system DLLs that are usually not present on the system (or at least not in system directories).
Usually this technique is used to achieve DLL hijacking.

rules.name: UEFI Persistence Via Wpbbin - FileCreation
rules.description: Detects creation of a file named "wpbbin" in the "%systemroot%\system32\" directory. Which could be indicative of UEFI based persistence method

rules.name: OneNote Attachment File Dropped In Suspicious Location
rules.description: Detects creation of files with the ".one"/".onepkg" extension in suspicious or uncommon locations. This could be a sign of attackers abusing OneNote attachments

rules.name: Potential Suspicious PowerShell Module File Created
rules.description: Detects the creation of a new PowerShell module in the first folder of the module directory structure "\WindowsPowerShell\Modules\malware\malware.psm1". This is somewhat an uncommon practice as legitimate modules often includes a version folder.

rules.name: NTDS.DIT Created
rules.description: Detects creation of a file named "ntds.dit" (Active Directory Database)

rules.name: Remote Access Tool - ScreenConnect Temporary File
rules.description:
Detects the creation of files in a specific location by ScreenConnect RMM.
ScreenConnect has feature to remotely execute binaries on a target machine. These binaries will be dropped to ":\Users\<username>\Documents\ConnectWiseControl\Temp\" before execution.

rules.name: Suspicious Creation with Colorcpl
rules.description: Once executed, colorcpl.exe will copy the arbitrary file to c:\windows\system32\spool\drivers\color\

rules.name: CSExec Service File Creation
rules.description: Detects default CSExec service filename which indicates CSExec service installation and execution

rules.name: Suspicious Interactive PowerShell as SYSTEM
rules.description: Detects the creation of files that indicator an interactive use of PowerShell in the SYSTEM user context

rules.name: GoToAssist Temporary Installation Artefact
rules.description:
An adversary may use legitimate desktop support and remote access software, such as Team Viewer, Go2Assist, LogMein, AmmyyAdmin, etc, to establish an interactive command and control channel to target systems within networks.
These services are commonly used as legitimate technical support software, and may be allowed by application control within a target environment.
Remote access tools like VNC, Ammyy, and Teamviewer are used frequently when compared with other legitimate software commonly used by adversaries. (Citation: Symantec Living off the Land)

rules.name: UAC Bypass Using IDiagnostic Profile - File
rules.description: Detects the creation of a file by "dllhost.exe" in System32 directory part of "IDiagnosticProfileUAC" UAC bypass technique

rules.name: Hijack Legit RDP Session to Move Laterally
rules.description: Detects the usage of tsclient share to place a backdoor on the RDP source machine's startup folder

rules.name: PCRE.NET Package Temp Files
rules.description: Detects processes creating temp files related to PCRE.NET package

rules.name: AWL Bypass with Winrm.vbs and Malicious WsmPty.xsl/WsmTxt.xsl - File
rules.description: Detects execution of attacker-controlled WsmPty.xsl or WsmTxt.xsl via winrm.vbs and copied cscript.exe (can be renamed)

rules.name: Creation of WerFault.exe/Wer.dll in Unusual Folder
rules.description: Detects the creation of a file named "WerFault.exe" or "wer.dll" in an uncommon folder, which could be a sign of WerFault DLL hijacking.

rules.name: WScript or CScript Dropper - File
rules.description: Detects a file ending in jse, vbe, js, vba, vbs written by cscript.exe or wscript.exe

rules.name: DPAPI Backup Keys And Certificate Export Activity IOC
rules.description: Detects file names with specific patterns seen generated and used by tools such as Mimikatz and DSInternals related to exported or stolen DPAPI backup keys and certificates.

rules.name: UAC Bypass Using MSConfig Token Modification - File
rules.description: Detects the pattern of UAC Bypass using a msconfig GUI hack (UACMe 55)

rules.name: Suspicious Get-Variable.exe Creation
rules.description:
Get-Variable is a valid PowerShell cmdlet
WindowsApps is by default in the path where PowerShell is executed.
So when the Get-Variable command is issued on PowerShell execution, the system first looks for the Get-Variable executable in the path and executes the malicious binary instead of looking for the PowerShell cmdlet.

rules.name: Wmiexec Default Output File
rules.description: Detects the creation of the default output filename used by the wmiexec tool

rules.name: Anydesk Temporary Artefact
rules.description:
An adversary may use legitimate desktop support and remote access software, such as Team Viewer, Go2Assist, LogMein, AmmyyAdmin, etc, to establish an interactive command and control channel to target systems within networks.
These services are commonly used as legitimate technical support software, and may be allowed by application control within a target environment.
Remote access tools like VNC, Ammyy, and Teamviewer are used frequently when compared with other legitimate software commonly used by adversaries. (Citation: Symantec Living off the Land)

rules.name: Potential Initial Access via DLL Search Order Hijacking
rules.description: Detects attempts to create a DLL file to a known desktop application dependencies folder such as Slack, Teams or OneDrive and by an unusual process. This may indicate an attempt to load a malicious module via DLL search order hijacking.

rules.name: Wmiprvse Wbemcomn DLL Hijack - File
rules.description: Detects a threat actor creating a file named `wbemcomn.dll` in the `C:\Windows\System32\wbem\` directory over the network and loading it for a WMI DLL Hijack scenario.

rules.name: Drop Binaries Into Spool Drivers Color Folder
rules.description: Detects the creation of suspcious binary files inside the "\windows\system32\spool\drivers\color\" as seen in the blog referenced below

rules.name: Potential File Extension Spoofing Using Right-to-Left Override
rules.description: Detects suspicious filenames that contain a right-to-left override character and a potentially spoofed file extensions.

rules.name: GatherNetworkInfo.VBS Reconnaissance Script Output
rules.description: Detects creation of files which are the results of executing the built-in reconnaissance script "C:\Windows\System32\gatherNetworkInfo.vbs".

rules.name: RemCom Service File Creation
rules.description: Detects default RemCom service filename which indicates RemCom service installation and execution

rules.name: HackTool - CrackMapExec File Indicators
rules.description: Detects file creation events with filename patterns used by CrackMapExec.

rules.name: HackTool - Potential Remote Credential Dumping Activity Via CrackMapExec Or Impacket-Secretsdump
rules.description: Detects default filenames output from the execution of CrackMapExec and Impacket-secretsdump against an endpoint.

rules.name: Windows Shell/Scripting Application File Write to Suspicious Folder
rules.description: Detects Windows shells and scripting applications that write files to suspicious folders

rules.name: .RDP File Created By Uncommon Application
rules.description: Detects creation of a file with an ".rdp" extension by an application that doesn't commonly create such files.

rules.name: PowerShell Profile Modification
rules.description: Detects the creation or modification of a powershell profile which could indicate suspicious activity as the profile can be used as a mean of persistence

rules.name: Suspicious Creation TXT File in User Desktop
rules.description: Ransomware create txt file in the user Desktop

rules.name: New Outlook Macro Created
rules.description: Detects the creation of a macro file for Outlook.

rules.name: Suspicious File Created In PerfLogs
rules.description: Detects suspicious file based on their extension being created in "C:\PerfLogs\". Note that this directory mostly contains ".etl" files

rules.name: BloodHound Collection Files
rules.description: Detects default file names outputted by the BloodHound collection tool SharpHound

rules.name: PowerShell Module File Created
rules.description: Detects the creation of a new PowerShell module ".psm1", ".psd1", ".dll", ".ps1", etc.

rules.name: Installation of TeamViewer Desktop
rules.description: TeamViewer_Desktop.exe is create during install

rules.name: Suspicious desktop.ini Action
rules.description: Detects unusual processes accessing desktop.ini, which can be leveraged to alter how Explorer displays a folder's content (i.e. renaming files) without changing them on disk.

rules.name: Publisher Attachment File Dropped In Suspicious Location
rules.description: Detects creation of files with the ".pub" extension in suspicious or uncommon locations. This could be a sign of attackers abusing Publisher documents

rules.name: PSScriptPolicyTest Creation By Uncommon Process
rules.description: Detects the creation of the "PSScriptPolicyTest" PowerShell script by an uncommon process. This file is usually generated by Microsoft Powershell to test against Applocker.

rules.name: LiveKD Driver Creation
rules.description: Detects the creation of the LiveKD driver, which is used for live kernel debugging

rules.name: File Creation In Suspicious Directory By Msdt.EXE
rules.description: Detects msdt.exe creating files in suspicious directories which could be a sign of exploitation of either Follina or Dogwalk vulnerabilities

rules.name: WerFault LSASS Process Memory Dump
rules.description: Detects WerFault creating a dump file with a name that indicates that the dump file could be an LSASS process memory, which contains user credentials

rules.name: DLL Search Order Hijackig Via Additional Space in Path
rules.description:
Detects when an attacker create a similar folder structure to windows system folders such as (Windows, Program Files...)
but with a space in order to trick DLL load search order and perform a "DLL Search Order Hijacking" attack

rules.name: Suspicious File Drop by Exchange
rules.description: Detects suspicious file type dropped by an Exchange component in IIS

rules.name: Office Macro File Creation
rules.description: Detects the creation of a new office macro files on the systems

rules.name: HackTool - SafetyKatz Dump Indicator
rules.description: Detects default lsass dump filename generated by SafetyKatz.

rules.name: Potential Persistence Via Outlook Form
rules.description: Detects the creation of a new Outlook form which can contain malicious code

rules.name: Potential Startup Shortcut Persistence Via PowerShell.EXE
rules.description:
Detects PowerShell writing startup shortcuts.
This procedure was highlighted in Red Canary Intel Insights Oct. 2021, "We frequently observe adversaries using PowerShell to write malicious .lnk files into the startup directory to establish persistence.
Accordingly, this detection opportunity is likely to identify persistence mechanisms in multiple threats.
In the context of Yellow Cockatoo, this persistence mechanism eventually launches the command-line script that leads to the installation of a malicious DLL"

rules.name: .RDP File Created by Outlook Process
rules.description:
Detects the creation of files with the ".rdp" extensions in the temporary directory that Outlook uses when opening attachments.
This can be used to detect spear-phishing campaigns that use RDP files as attachments.

rules.name: HackTool - Dumpert Process Dumper Default File
rules.description: Detects the creation of the default dump file used by Outflank Dumpert tool. A process dumper, which dumps the lsass process memory

rules.name: Process Explorer Driver Creation By Non-Sysinternals Binary
rules.description:
Detects creation of the Process Explorer drivers by processes other than Process Explorer (procexp) itself.
Hack tools or malware may use the Process Explorer driver to elevate privileges, drops it to disk for a few moments, runs a service using that driver and removes it afterwards.

rules.name: Suspicious Screensaver Binary File Creation
rules.description:
Adversaries may establish persistence by executing malicious content triggered by user inactivity.
Screensavers are programs that execute after a configurable time of user inactivity and consist of Portable Executable (PE) files with a .scr file extension

rules.name: Suspicious DotNET CLR Usage Log Artifact
rules.description: Detects the creation of Usage Log files by the CLR (clr.dll). These files are named after the executing process once the assembly is finished executing for the first time in the (user) session context.

rules.name: Adwind RAT / JRAT File Artifact
rules.description: Detects javaw.exe in AppData folder as used by Adwind / JRAT

rules.name: SCR File Write Event
rules.description: Detects the creation of screensaver files (.scr) outside of system folders. Attackers may execute an application as an ".SCR" file using "rundll32.exe desk.cpl,InstallScreenSaver" for example.

rules.name: Windows Binaries Write Suspicious Extensions
rules.description: Detects Windows executables that write files with suspicious extensions

rules.name: VHD Image Download Via Browser
rules.description:
Detects creation of ".vhd"/".vhdx" files by browser processes.
Malware can use mountable Virtual Hard Disk ".vhd" files to encapsulate payloads and evade security controls.

rules.name: Renamed VsCode Code Tunnel Execution - File Indicator
rules.description: Detects the creation of a file with the name "code_tunnel.json" which indicate execution and usage of VsCode tunneling utility by an "Image" or "Process" other than VsCode.

rules.name: Suspicious Outlook Macro Created
rules.description: Detects the creation of a macro file for Outlook.

rules.name: PsExec Service File Creation
rules.description: Detects default PsExec service filename which indicates PsExec service installation and execution

rules.name: HackTool - Mimikatz Kirbi File Creation
rules.description: Detects the creation of files created by mimikatz such as ".kirbi", "mimilsa.log", etc.

rules.name: Potentially Suspicious WDAC Policy File Creation
rules.description: Detects suspicious Windows Defender Application Control (WDAC) policy file creation from abnormal processes that could be abused by attacker to block EDR/AV components while allowing their own malicious code to run on the system.

rules.name: NTDS.DIT Creation By Uncommon Parent Process
rules.description: Detects creation of a file named "ntds.dit" (Active Directory Database) by an uncommon parent process or directory

rules.name: Uncommon File Creation By Mysql Daemon Process
rules.description:
Detects the creation of files with scripting or executable extensions by Mysql daemon.
Which could be an indicator of "User Defined Functions" abuse to download malware.

rules.name: IIS WebServer Access Logs Deleted
rules.description: Detects the deletion of IIS WebServer access logs which may indicate an attempt to destroy forensic evidence

rules.name: ADS Zone.Identifier Deleted By Uncommon Application
rules.description: Detects the deletion of the "Zone.Identifier" ADS by an uncommon process. Attackers can leverage this in order to bypass security restrictions that make use of the ADS such as Microsoft Office apps.

rules.name: Tomcat WebServer Logs Deleted
rules.description: Detects the deletion of tomcat WebServer logs which may indicate an attempt to destroy forensic evidence

rules.name: Unusual File Deletion by Dns.exe
rules.description: Detects an unexpected file being deleted by dns.exe which my indicate activity related to remote code execution or other forms of exploitation as seen in CVE-2020-1350 (SigRed)

rules.name: Process Deletion of Its Own Executable
rules.description: Detects the deletion of a process's executable by itself. This is usually not possible without workarounds and may be used by malware to hide its traces.

rules.name: Backup Files Deleted
rules.description: Detects deletion of files with extensions often used for backup files. Adversaries may delete or remove built-in operating system data and turn off services designed to aid in the recovery of a corrupted system to prevent recovery.

rules.name: File Deleted Via Sysinternals SDelete
rules.description: Detects the deletion of files by the Sysinternals SDelete utility. It looks for the common name pattern used to rename files.

rules.name: TeamViewer Log File Deleted
rules.description: Detects the deletion of the TeamViewer log files which may indicate an attempt to destroy forensic evidence

rules.name: Exchange PowerShell Cmdlet History Deleted
rules.description: Detects the deletion of the Exchange PowerShell cmdlet History logs which may indicate an attempt to destroy forensic evidence

rules.name: Prefetch File Deleted
rules.description: Detects the deletion of a prefetch file which may indicate an attempt to destroy forensic evidence

rules.name: Potential PrintNightmare Exploitation Attempt
rules.description: Detect DLL deletions from Spooler Service driver folder. This might be a potential exploitation attempt of CVE-2021-1675

rules.name: EventLog EVTX File Deleted
rules.description: Detects the deletion of the event log files which may indicate an attempt to destroy forensic evidence

rules.name: PowerShell Console History Logs Deleted
rules.description: Detects the deletion of the PowerShell console History logs which may indicate an attempt to destroy forensic evidence

rules.name: Access To Crypto Currency Wallets By Uncommon Applications
rules.description:
Detects file access requests to crypto currency files by uncommon processes.
Could indicate potential attempt of crypto currency wallet stealing.

rules.name: Credential Manager Access By Uncommon Applications
rules.description:
Detects suspicious processes based on name and location that access the windows credential manager and vault.
Which can be a sign of credential stealing. Example case would be usage of mimikatz "dpapi::cred" function

rules.name: Access To Potentially Sensitive Sysvol Files By Uncommon Applications
rules.description: Detects file access requests to potentially sensitive files hosted on the Windows Sysvol share.

rules.name: Access To Windows DPAPI Master Keys By Uncommon Applications
rules.description:
Detects file access requests to the the Windows Data Protection API Master keys by an uncommon application.
This can be a sign of credential stealing. Example case would be usage of mimikatz "dpapi::masterkey" function

rules.name: Access To Windows Credential History File By Uncommon Applications
rules.description:
Detects file access requests to the Windows Credential History File by an uncommon application.
This can be a sign of credential stealing. Example case would be usage of mimikatz "dpapi::credhist" function

rules.name: Microsoft Teams Sensitive File Access By Uncommon Applications
rules.description: Detects file access attempts to sensitive Microsoft teams files (leveldb, cookies) by an uncommon process.

rules.name: File Creation Date Changed to Another Year
rules.description:
Attackers may change the file creation time of a backdoor to make it look like it was installed with the operating system.
Note that many processes legitimately change the creation time of a file; it does not necessarily indicate malicious activity.

rules.name: Unusual File Modification by dns.exe
rules.description: Detects an unexpected file being modified by dns.exe which my indicate activity related to remote code execution or other forms of exploitation as seen in CVE-2020-1350 (SigRed)

rules.name: Suspicious Scripting in a WMI Consumer
rules.description: Detects suspicious commands that are related to scripting/powershell in WMI Event Consumers

rules.name: Suspicious Encoded Scripts in a WMI Consumer
rules.description: Detects suspicious encoded payloads in WMI Event Consumers

rules.name: WMI Event Subscription
rules.description: Detects creation of WMI event subscription persistence method

rules.name: Tamper Windows Defender - PSClassic
rules.description: Attempting to disable scheduled scanning and other parts of Windows Defender ATP or set default actions to allow.

rules.name: Nslookup PowerShell Download Cradle
rules.description: Detects a powershell download cradle using nslookup. This cradle uses nslookup to extract payloads from DNS records.

rules.name: Potential RemoteFXvGPUDisablement.EXE Abuse
rules.description: Detects PowerShell module creation where the module Contents are set to "function Get-VMRemoteFXPhysicalVideoAdapter". This could be a sign of potential abuse of  the "RemoteFXvGPUDisablement.exe" binary which is known to be vulnerable to module load-order hijacking.

rules.name: Delete Volume Shadow Copies Via WMI With PowerShell
rules.description: Shadow Copies deletion using operating systems utilities via PowerShell

rules.name: PowerShell Downgrade Attack - PowerShell
rules.description: Detects PowerShell downgrade attack by comparing the host versions with the actually used engine version 2.0

rules.name: Use Get-NetTCPConnection
rules.description: Adversaries may attempt to get a listing of network connections to or from the compromised system they are currently accessing or from remote systems by querying for information over the network.

rules.name: PowerShell Called from an Executable Version Mismatch
rules.description: Detects PowerShell called from an executable by the version mismatch method

rules.name: Suspicious Non PowerShell WSMAN COM Provider
rules.description: Detects suspicious use of the WSMAN provider without PowerShell.exe as the host application.

rules.name: Suspicious PowerShell Download
rules.description: Detects suspicious PowerShell download command

rules.name: Remote PowerShell Session (PS Classic)
rules.description: Detects remote PowerShell sessions

rules.name: Renamed Powershell Under Powershell Channel
rules.description: Detects a renamed Powershell execution, which is a common technique used to circumvent security controls and bypass detection logic that's dependent on process names and process paths.

rules.name: Netcat The Powershell Version
rules.description: Adversaries may use a non-application layer protocol for communication between host and C2 server or among infected hosts within a network

rules.name: Zip A Folder With PowerShell For Staging In Temp - PowerShell
rules.description:
Detects PowerShell scripts that make use of the "Compress-Archive" Cmdlet in order to compress folders and files where the output is stored in a potentially suspicious location that is used often by malware for exfiltration.
An adversary might compress data (e.g., sensitive documents) that is collected prior to exfiltration in order to make it portable and minimize the amount of data sent over the network.

rules.name: Suspicious PowerShell Get Current User
rules.description: Detects the use of PowerShell to identify the current logged user.

rules.name: Powershell XML Execute Command
rules.description:
Adversaries may abuse PowerShell commands and scripts for execution.
PowerShell is a powerful interactive command-line interface and scripting environment included in the Windows operating system. (Citation: TechNet PowerShell)
Adversaries can use PowerShell to perform a number of actions, including discovery of information and execution of code

rules.name: HackTool - WinPwn Execution - ScriptBlock
rules.description: Detects scriptblock text keywords indicative of potential usge of the tool WinPwn. A tool for Windows and Active Directory reconnaissance and exploitation.

rules.name: Testing Usage of Uncommonly Used Port
rules.description:
Adversaries may communicate using a protocol and port paring that are typically not associated.
For example, HTTPS over port 8088(Citation: Symantec Elfin Mar 2019) or port 587(Citation: Fortinet Agent Tesla April 2018) as opposed to the traditional port 443.

rules.name: Windows Screen Capture with CopyFromScreen
rules.description:
Adversaries may attempt to take screen captures of the desktop to gather information over the course of an operation.
Screen capturing functionality may be included as a feature of a remote access tool used in post-compromise operations

rules.name: Disable Powershell Command History
rules.description: Detects scripts or commands that disabled the Powershell command history by removing psreadline module

rules.name: Suspicious PowerShell Mailbox Export to Share - PS
rules.description: Detects usage of the powerShell New-MailboxExportRequest Cmdlet to exports a mailbox to a remote or local share, as used in ProxyShell exploitations

rules.name: Root Certificate Installed - PowerShell
rules.description: Adversaries may install a root certificate on a compromised system to avoid warnings when connecting to adversary controlled web servers.

rules.name: Suspicious Service DACL Modification Via Set-Service Cmdlet - PS
rules.description: Detects usage of the "Set-Service" powershell cmdlet to configure a new SecurityDescriptor that allows a service to be hidden from other utilities such as "sc.exe", "Get-Service"...etc. (Works only in powershell 7)

rules.name: PowerShell Credential Prompt
rules.description: Detects PowerShell calling a credential prompt

rules.name: Active Directory Group Enumeration With Get-AdGroup
rules.description: Detects usage of the "Get-AdGroup" cmdlet to enumerate Groups within Active Directory

rules.name: Suspicious PowerShell Download - Powershell Script
rules.description: Detects suspicious PowerShell download command

rules.name: DSInternals Suspicious PowerShell Cmdlets - ScriptBlock
rules.description:
Detects execution and usage of the DSInternals PowerShell module. Which can be used to perform what might be considered as suspicious activity such as dumping DPAPI backup keys or manipulating NTDS.DIT files.
The DSInternals PowerShell Module exposes several internal features of Active Directory and Azure Active Directory. These include FIDO2 and NGC key auditing, offline ntds.dit file manipulation, password auditing, DC recovery from IFM backups and password hash calculation.

rules.name: Tamper Windows Defender - ScriptBlockLogging
rules.description: Detects PowerShell scripts attempting to disable scheduled scanning and other parts of Windows Defender ATP or set default actions to allow.

rules.name: Suspicious PowerShell Invocations - Generic
rules.description: Detects suspicious PowerShell invocation command parameters

rules.name: Potential Data Exfiltration Via Audio File
rules.description: Detects potential exfiltration attempt via audio file using PowerShell

rules.name: Invoke-Obfuscation Obfuscated IEX Invocation - PowerShell
rules.description: Detects all variations of obfuscated powershell IEX invocation code generated by Invoke-Obfuscation framework from the following code block \u2014

rules.name: PowerShell Set-Acl On Windows Folder - PsScript
rules.description: Detects PowerShell scripts to set the ACL to a file in the Windows folder

rules.name: Automated Collection Command PowerShell
rules.description: Once established within a system or network, an adversary may use automated techniques for collecting internal data.

rules.name: Modify Group Policy Settings - ScriptBlockLogging
rules.description: Detect malicious GPO modifications can be used to implement many other malicious behaviors.

rules.name: Potentially Suspicious Call To Win32_NTEventlogFile Class - PSScript
rules.description: Detects usage of the WMI class "Win32_NTEventlogFile" in a potentially suspicious way (delete, backup, change permissions, etc.) from a PowerShell script

rules.name: Winlogon Helper DLL
rules.description:
Winlogon.exe is a Windows component responsible for actions at logon/logoff as well as the secure attention sequence (SAS) triggered by Ctrl-Alt-Delete.
Registry entries in HKLM\Software[Wow6432Node]Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon\ and HKCU\Software\Microsoft\Windows NT\CurrentVersion\Winlogon\ are
used to manage additional helper programs and functionalities that support Winlogon. Malicious modifications to these Registry keys may cause Winlogon to
load and execute malicious DLLs and/or executables.

rules.name: Access to Browser Login Data
rules.description:
Adversaries may acquire credentials from web browsers by reading files specific to the target browser.
Web browsers commonly save credentials such as website usernames and passwords so that they do not need to be entered manually in the future.
Web browsers typically store the credentials in an encrypted format within a credential store.

rules.name: PowerShell Web Access Installation - PsScript
rules.description: Detects the installation and configuration of PowerShell Web Access, which could be used for remote access and potential abuse

rules.name: Recon Information for Export with PowerShell
rules.description: Once established within a system or network, an adversary may use automated techniques for collecting internal data

rules.name: Suspicious SSL Connection
rules.description: Adversaries may employ a known encryption algorithm to conceal command and control traffic rather than relying on any inherent protections provided by a communication protocol.

rules.name: Invoke-Obfuscation CLIP+ Launcher - PowerShell
rules.description: Detects Obfuscated use of Clip.exe to execute PowerShell

rules.name: Abuse of Service Permissions to Hide Services Via Set-Service - PS
rules.description: Detects usage of the "Set-Service" powershell cmdlet to configure a new SecurityDescriptor that allows a service to be hidden from other utilities such as "sc.exe", "Get-Service"...etc. (Works only in powershell 7)

rules.name: Potential Suspicious PowerShell Keywords
rules.description: Detects potentially suspicious keywords that could indicate the use of a PowerShell exploitation framework

rules.name: Potential Keylogger Activity
rules.description: Detects PowerShell scripts that contains reference to keystroke capturing functions

rules.name: WMImplant Hack Tool
rules.description: Detects parameters used by WMImplant

rules.name: Invoke-Obfuscation Via Use MSHTA - PowerShell
rules.description: Detects Obfuscated Powershell via use MSHTA in Scripts

rules.name: Unsigned AppX Installation Attempt Using Add-AppxPackage - PsScript
rules.description: Detects usage of the "Add-AppxPackage" or it's alias "Add-AppPackage" to install unsigned AppX packages

rules.name: Get-ADUser Enumeration Using UserAccountControl Flags
rules.description: Detects AS-REP roasting is an attack that is often-overlooked. It is not very common as you have to explicitly set accounts that do not require pre-authentication.

rules.name: Add Windows Capability Via PowerShell Script
rules.description: Detects usage of the "Add-WindowsCapability" cmdlet to add Windows capabilities. Notable capabilities could be "OpenSSH" and others.

rules.name: Invoke-Obfuscation Via Stdin - Powershell
rules.description: Detects Obfuscated Powershell via Stdin in Scripts

rules.name: Create Volume Shadow Copy with Powershell
rules.description: Adversaries may attempt to access or create a copy of the Active Directory domain database in order to steal credential information

rules.name: HackTool - Rubeus Execution - ScriptBlock
rules.description: Detects the execution of the hacktool Rubeus using specific command line flags

rules.name: Potential AMSI Bypass Script Using NULL Bits
rules.description: Detects usage of special strings/null bits in order to potentially bypass AMSI functionalities

rules.name: Suspicious IO.FileStream
rules.description: Open a handle on the drive volume via the \\.\ DOS device path specifier and perform direct access read of the first few bytes of the volume.

rules.name: Malicious Nishang PowerShell Commandlets
rules.description: Detects Commandlet names and arguments from the Nishang exploitation framework

rules.name: Powershell Create Scheduled Task
rules.description: Adversaries may abuse the Windows Task Scheduler to perform task scheduling for initial or recurring execution of malicious code

rules.name: SyncAppvPublishingServer Execution to Bypass Powershell Restriction
rules.description: Detects SyncAppvPublishingServer process execution which usually utilized by adversaries to bypass PowerShell execution restrictions.

rules.name: Enumerate Credentials from Windows Credential Manager With PowerShell
rules.description:
Adversaries may search for common password storage locations to obtain user credentials.
Passwords are stored in several places on a system, depending on the operating system or application holding the credentials.

rules.name: Powershell DNSExfiltration
rules.description: DNSExfiltrator allows for transferring (exfiltrate) a file over a DNS request covert channel

rules.name: User Discovery And Export Via Get-ADUser Cmdlet - PowerShell
rules.description: Detects usage of the Get-ADUser cmdlet to collect user information and output it to a file

rules.name: Invoke-Obfuscation Via Use Clip - Powershell
rules.description: Detects Obfuscated Powershell via use Clip.exe in Scripts

rules.name: Powershell Directory Enumeration
rules.description: Detects technique used by MAZE ransomware to enumerate directories using Powershell

rules.name: Change User Agents with WebRequest
rules.description:
Adversaries may communicate using application layer protocols associated with web traffic to avoid detection/network filtering by blending in with existing traffic.
Commands to the remote system, and often the results of those commands, will be embedded within the protocol traffic between the client and server.

rules.name: Enable Windows Remote Management
rules.description: Adversaries may use Valid Accounts to interact with remote systems using Windows Remote Management (WinRM). The adversary may then perform actions as the logged-on user.

rules.name: Suspicious GetTypeFromCLSID ShellExecute
rules.description: Detects suspicious Powershell code that execute COM Objects

rules.name: Disable-WindowsOptionalFeature Command PowerShell
rules.description:
Detect built in PowerShell cmdlet Disable-WindowsOptionalFeature, Deployment Image Servicing and Management tool.
Similar to DISM.exe, this cmdlet is used to enumerate, install, uninstall, configure, and update features and packages in Windows images

rules.name: Potential Unconstrained Delegation Discovery Via Get-ADComputer - ScriptBlock
rules.description: Detects the use of the "Get-ADComputer" cmdlet in order to identify systems which are configured for unconstrained delegation.

rules.name: Zip A Folder With PowerShell For Staging In Temp - PowerShell Script
rules.description:
Detects PowerShell scripts that make use of the "Compress-Archive" Cmdlet in order to compress folders and files where the output is stored in a potentially suspicious location that is used often by malware for exfiltration.
An adversary might compress data (e.g., sensitive documents) that is collected prior to exfiltration in order to make it portable and minimize the amount of data sent over the network.

rules.name: Replace Desktop Wallpaper by Powershell
rules.description:
An adversary may deface systems internal to an organization in an attempt to intimidate or mislead users.
This may take the form of modifications to internal websites, or directly to user systems with the replacement of the desktop wallpaper

rules.name: PowerShell WMI Win32_Product Install MSI
rules.description: Detects the execution of an MSI file using PowerShell and the WMI Win32_Product class

rules.name: Powershell Keylogging
rules.description: Adversaries may log user keystrokes to intercept credentials as the user types them.

rules.name: Powershell Local Email Collection
rules.description:
Adversaries may target user email on local systems to collect sensitive information.
Files containing email data can be acquired from a users local system, such as Outlook storage or cache files.

rules.name: Suspicious X509Enrollment - Ps Script
rules.description: Detect use of X509Enrollment

rules.name: Import PowerShell Modules From Suspicious Directories
rules.description: Detects powershell scripts that import modules from suspicious directories

rules.name: Invoke-Obfuscation STDIN+ Launcher - Powershell
rules.description: Detects Obfuscated use of stdin to execute PowerShell

rules.name: Invoke-Obfuscation VAR++ LAUNCHER OBFUSCATION - PowerShell
rules.description: Detects Obfuscated Powershell via VAR++ LAUNCHER

rules.name: Extracting Information with PowerShell
rules.description:
Adversaries may search local file systems and remote file shares for files containing insecurely stored credentials.
These can be files created by users to store their own credentials, shared credential stores for a group of individuals,
configuration files containing passwords for a system or service, or source code/binary files containing embedded passwords.

rules.name: Detected Windows Software Discovery - PowerShell
rules.description: Adversaries may attempt to enumerate software for a variety of reasons, such as figuring out what security measures are present or if the compromised system has a version of software that is vulnerable.

rules.name: Suspicious Start-Process PassThru
rules.description: Powershell use PassThru option to start in background

rules.name: PowerShell Script With File Upload Capabilities
rules.description: Detects PowerShell scripts leveraging the "Invoke-WebRequest" cmdlet to send data via either "PUT" or "POST" method.

rules.name: Potential Invoke-Mimikatz PowerShell Script
rules.description: Detects Invoke-Mimikatz PowerShell script and alike. Mimikatz is a credential dumper capable of obtaining plaintext Windows account logins and passwords.

rules.name: Suspicious Process Discovery With Get-Process
rules.description: Get the processes that are running on the local computer.

rules.name: Malicious PowerShell Commandlets - ScriptBlock
rules.description: Detects Commandlet names from well-known PowerShell exploitation frameworks

rules.name: Potential COM Objects Download Cradles Usage - PS Script
rules.description: Detects usage of COM objects that can be abused to download files in PowerShell by CLSID

rules.name: Suspicious Invoke-Item From Mount-DiskImage
rules.description: Adversaries may abuse container files such as disk image (.iso, .vhd) file formats to deliver malicious payloads that may not be tagged with MOTW.

rules.name: Request A Single Ticket via PowerShell
rules.description:
utilize native PowerShell Identity modules to query the domain to extract the Service Principal Names for a single computer.
This behavior is typically used during a kerberos or silver ticket attack.
A successful execution will output the SPNs for the endpoint in question.

rules.name: Veeam Backup Servers Credential Dumping Script Execution
rules.description: Detects execution of a PowerShell script that contains calls to the "Veeam.Backup" class, in order to dump stored credentials.

rules.name: Potential Suspicious Windows Feature Enabled
rules.description:
Detects usage of the built-in PowerShell cmdlet "Enable-WindowsOptionalFeature" used as a Deployment Image Servicing and Management tool.
Similar to DISM.exe, this cmdlet is used to enumerate, install, uninstall, configure, and update features and packages in Windows images

rules.name: PowerView PowerShell Cmdlets - ScriptBlock
rules.description: Detects Cmdlet names from PowerView of the PowerSploit exploitation framework.

rules.name: Malicious ShellIntel PowerShell Commandlets
rules.description: Detects Commandlet names from ShellIntel exploitation scripts.

rules.name: Computer Discovery And Export Via Get-ADComputer Cmdlet - PowerShell
rules.description: Detects usage of the Get-ADComputer cmdlet to collect computer information and output it to a file

rules.name: Potential RemoteFXvGPUDisablement.EXE Abuse - PowerShell ScriptBlock
rules.description: Detects PowerShell module creation where the module Contents are set to "function Get-VMRemoteFXPhysicalVideoAdapter". This could be a sign of potential abuse of the "RemoteFXvGPUDisablement.exe" binary which is known to be vulnerable to module load-order hijacking.

rules.name: PowerShell Remote Session Creation
rules.description:
Adversaries may abuse PowerShell commands and scripts for execution.
PowerShell is a powerful interactive command-line interface and scripting environment included in the Windows operating system

rules.name: Suspicious Get Information for SMB Share
rules.description:
Adversaries may look for folders and drives shared on remote systems as a means of identifying sources of information to gather as
a precursor for Collection and to identify potential systems of interest for Lateral Movement.
Networks often contain shared network drives and folders that enable users to access file directories on various systems across a network.

rules.name: DirectorySearcher Powershell Exploitation
rules.description: Enumerates Active Directory to determine computers that are joined to the domain

rules.name: PowerShell ADRecon Execution
rules.description: Detects execution of ADRecon.ps1 for AD reconnaissance which has been reported to be actively used by FIN7

rules.name: Suspicious Get Local Groups Information - PowerShell
rules.description:
Adversaries may attempt to find local system groups and permission settings.
The knowledge of local system permission groups can help adversaries determine which groups exist and which users belong to a particular group.
Adversaries may use this information to determine which users have elevated permissions, such as the users found within the local administrators group.

rules.name: Password Policy Discovery With Get-AdDefaultDomainPasswordPolicy
rules.description: Detetcts PowerShell activity in which Get-Addefaultdomainpasswordpolicy is used to get the default password policy for an Active Directory domain.

rules.name: Suspicious Eventlog Clear
rules.description: Detects usage of known powershell cmdlets such as "Clear-EventLog" to clear the Windows event logs

rules.name: PSAsyncShell - Asynchronous TCP Reverse Shell
rules.description: Detects the use of PSAsyncShell an Asynchronous TCP Reverse Shell written in powershell

rules.name: Silence.EDA Detection
rules.description: Detects Silence EmpireDNSAgent as described in the Group-IP report

rules.name: Powershell Token Obfuscation - Powershell
rules.description: Detects TOKEN OBFUSCATION technique from Invoke-Obfuscation

rules.name: Code Executed Via Office Add-in XLL File
rules.description:
Adversaries may abuse Microsoft Office add-ins to obtain persistence on a compromised system.
Office add-ins can be used to add functionality to Office programs

rules.name: Potential WinAPI Calls Via PowerShell Scripts
rules.description: Detects use of WinAPI functions in PowerShell scripts

rules.name: Tamper Windows Defender Remove-MpPreference - ScriptBlockLogging
rules.description: Detects attempts to remove Windows Defender configuration using the 'MpPreference' cmdlet

rules.name: Powershell Add Name Resolution Policy Table Rule
rules.description:
Detects powershell scripts that adds a Name Resolution Policy Table (NRPT) rule for the specified namespace.
This will bypass the default DNS server and uses a specified server for answering the query.

rules.name: Deletion of Volume Shadow Copies via WMI with PowerShell - PS Script
rules.description: Detects deletion of Windows Volume Shadow Copies with PowerShell code and Get-WMIObject. This technique is used by numerous ransomware families such as Sodinokibi/REvil

rules.name: Delete Volume Shadow Copies via WMI with PowerShell - PS Script
rules.description: Deletes Windows Volume Shadow Copies with PowerShell code and Get-WMIObject. This technique is used by numerous ransomware families such as Sodinokibi/REvil

rules.name: Disable of ETW Trace - Powershell
rules.description: Detects usage of powershell cmdlets to disable or remove ETW trace sessions

rules.name: Suspicious PowerShell Mailbox SMTP Forward Rule
rules.description: Detects usage of the powerShell Set-Mailbox Cmdlet to set-up an SMTP forwarding rule.

rules.name: Automated Collection Bookmarks Using Get-ChildItem PowerShell
rules.description:
Adversaries may enumerate browser bookmarks to learn more about compromised hosts.
Browser bookmarks may reveal personal information about users (ex: banking sites, interests, social media, etc.) as well as details about
internal network resources such as servers, tools/dashboards, or other related infrastructure.

rules.name: Suspicious New-PSDrive to Admin Share
rules.description: Adversaries may use to interact with a remote network share using Server Message Block (SMB). The adversary may then perform actions as the logged-on user.

rules.name: AADInternals PowerShell Cmdlets Execution - PsScript
rules.description: Detects ADDInternals Cmdlet execution. A tool for administering Azure AD and Office 365. Which can be abused by threat actors to attack Azure AD or Office 365.

rules.name: Suspicious PowerShell WindowStyle Option
rules.description:
Adversaries may use hidden windows to conceal malicious activity from the plain sight of users.
In some cases, windows that would typically be displayed when an application carries out an operation can be hidden

rules.name: Clear PowerShell History - PowerShell
rules.description: Detects keywords that could indicate clearing PowerShell history

rules.name: PowerShell Hotfix Enumeration
rules.description: Detects call to "Win32_QuickFixEngineering" in order to enumerate installed hotfixes often used in "enum" scripts by attackers

rules.name: Suspicious Hyper-V Cmdlets
rules.description: Adversaries may carry out malicious operations using a virtual instance to avoid detection

rules.name: Remove Account From Domain Admin Group
rules.description:
Adversaries may interrupt availability of system and network resources by inhibiting access to accounts utilized by legitimate users.
Accounts may be deleted, locked, or manipulated (ex: changed credentials) to remove access to accounts.

rules.name: Powershell Timestomp
rules.description:
Adversaries may modify file time attributes to hide new or changes to existing files.
Timestomping is a technique that modifies the timestamps of a file (the modify, access, create, and change times), often to mimic files that are in the same folder.

rules.name: Suspicious GPO Discovery With Get-GPO
rules.description: Detect use of Get-GPO to get one GPO or all the GPOs in a domain.

rules.name: Potential PowerShell Obfuscation Using Character Join
rules.description: Detects specific techniques often seen used inside of PowerShell scripts to obfscuate Alias creation

rules.name: Invoke-Obfuscation COMPRESS OBFUSCATION - PowerShell
rules.description: Detects Obfuscated Powershell via COMPRESS OBFUSCATION

rules.name: PowerShell Get-Process LSASS in ScriptBlock
rules.description: Detects a Get-Process command on lsass process, which is in almost all cases a sign of malicious activity

rules.name: Security Software Discovery Via Powershell Script
rules.description:
Detects calls to "get-process" where the output is piped to a "where-object" filter to search for security solution processes.
Adversaries may attempt to get a listing of security software, configurations, defensive tools, and sensors that are installed on a system or in a cloud environment. This may include things such as firewall rules and anti-virus

rules.name: Potential Packet Capture Activity Via Start-NetEventSession - ScriptBlock
rules.description:
Detects the execution of powershell scripts with calls to the "Start-NetEventSession" cmdlet. Which allows an attacker to start event and packet capture for a network event session.
Adversaries may attempt to capture network to gather information over the course of an operation.
Data captured via this technique may include user credentials, especially those sent over an insecure, unencrypted protocol.

rules.name: Live Memory Dump Using Powershell
rules.description: Detects usage of a PowerShell command to dump the live memory of a Windows machine

rules.name: Powershell LocalAccount Manipulation
rules.description:
Adversaries may manipulate accounts to maintain access to victim systems.
Account manipulation may consist of any action that preserves adversary access to a compromised account, such as modifying credentials or permission groups

rules.name: Potential Persistence Via PowerShell User Profile Using Add-Content
rules.description: Detects calls to "Add-Content" cmdlet in order to modify the content of the user profile and potentially adding suspicious commands for persistence

rules.name: Potential PowerShell Obfuscation Using Alias Cmdlets
rules.description: Detects Set-Alias or New-Alias cmdlet usage. Which can be use as a mean to obfuscate PowerShell scripts

rules.name: Manipulation of User Computer or Group Security Principals Across AD
rules.description:
Adversaries may create a domain account to maintain access to victim systems.
Domain accounts are those managed by Active Directory Domain Services where access and permissions are configured across systems and services that are part of that domain..

rules.name: PowerShell Deleted Mounted Share
rules.description: Detects when when a mounted share is removed. Adversaries may remove share connections that are no longer useful in order to clean up traces of their operation

rules.name: Suspicious TCP Tunnel Via PowerShell Script
rules.description: Detects powershell scripts that creates sockets/listeners which could be indicative of tunneling activity

rules.name: Invoke-Obfuscation Via Use Rundll32 - PowerShell
rules.description: Detects Obfuscated Powershell via use Rundll32 in Scripts

rules.name: Suspicious Mount-DiskImage
rules.description: Adversaries may abuse container files such as disk image (.iso, .vhd) file formats to deliver malicious payloads that may not be tagged with MOTW.

rules.name: Windows Firewall Profile Disabled
rules.description: Detects when a user disables the Windows Firewall via a Profile to help evade defense.

rules.name: PowerShell Script With File Hostname Resolving Capabilities
rules.description: Detects PowerShell scripts that have capabilities to read files, loop through them and resolve DNS host entries.

rules.name: Registry-Free Process Scope COR_PROFILER
rules.description:
Adversaries may leverage the COR_PROFILER environment variable to hijack the execution flow of programs that load the .NET CLR.
The COR_PROFILER is a .NET Framework feature which allows developers to specify an unmanaged (or external of .NET) profiling DLL to be loaded into each .NET process that loads the Common Language Runtime (CLR).
These profiliers are designed to monitor, troubleshoot, and debug managed code executed by the .NET CLR.
(Citation: Microsoft Profiling Mar 2017)
(Citation: Microsoft COR_PROFILER Feb 2013)

rules.name: Windows Defender Exclusions Added - PowerShell
rules.description: Detects modifications to the Windows Defender configuration settings using PowerShell to add exclusions

rules.name: Powershell WMI Persistence
rules.description: Adversaries may establish persistence and elevate privileges by executing malicious content triggered by a Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI) event subscription.

rules.name: PowerShell ShellCode
rules.description: Detects Base64 encoded Shellcode

rules.name: PowerShell Script Change Permission Via Set-Acl - PsScript
rules.description: Detects PowerShell scripts set ACL to of a file or a folder

rules.name: PowerShell Write-EventLog Usage
rules.description: Detects usage of the "Write-EventLog" cmdlet with 'RawData' flag. The cmdlet can be levreage to write malicious payloads to the EventLog and then retrieve them later for later use

rules.name: Change PowerShell Policies to an Insecure Level - PowerShell
rules.description: Detects changing the PowerShell script execution policy to a potentially insecure level using the "Set-ExecutionPolicy" cmdlet.

rules.name: Powershell MsXml COM Object
rules.description:
Adversaries may abuse PowerShell commands and scripts for execution.
PowerShell is a powerful interactive command-line interface and scripting environment included in the Windows operating system. (Citation: TechNet PowerShell)
Adversaries can use PowerShell to perform a number of actions, including discovery of information and execution of code

rules.name: Suspicious PowerShell Invocations - Specific
rules.description: Detects suspicious PowerShell invocation command parameters

rules.name: Powershell Install a DLL in System Directory
rules.description: Uses PowerShell to install/copy a file into a system directory such as "System32" or "SysWOW64"

rules.name: Powershell Store File In Alternate Data Stream
rules.description: Storing files in Alternate Data Stream (ADS) similar to Astaroth malware.

rules.name: PowerShell ICMP Exfiltration
rules.description: Detects Exfiltration Over Alternative Protocol - ICMP. Adversaries may steal data by exfiltrating it over an un-encrypted network protocol other than that of the existing command and control channel.

rules.name: PowerShell PSAttack
rules.description: Detects the use of PSAttack PowerShell hack tool

rules.name: Troubleshooting Pack Cmdlet Execution
rules.description: Detects execution of "TroubleshootingPack" cmdlets to leverage CVE-2022-30190 or action similar to "msdt" lolbin (as described in LOLBAS)

rules.name: NTFS Alternate Data Stream
rules.description: Detects writing data into NTFS alternate data streams from powershell. Needs Script Block Logging.

rules.name: Potential Active Directory Enumeration Using AD Module - PsScript
rules.description: Detects usage of the "Import-Module" cmdlet to load the "Microsoft.ActiveDirectory.Management.dl" DLL. Which is often used by attackers to perform AD enumeration.

rules.name: Certificate Exported Via PowerShell - ScriptBlock
rules.description: Detects calls to cmdlets inside of PowerShell scripts that are used to export certificates from the local certificate store. Threat actors were seen abusing this to steal private keys from compromised machines.

rules.name: Powershell Sensitive File Discovery
rules.description: Detect adversaries enumerate sensitive files

rules.name: Powershell Detect Virtualization Environment
rules.description:
Adversaries may employ various system checks to detect and avoid virtualization and analysis environments.
This may include changing behaviors based on the results of checks for the presence of artifacts indicative of a virtual machine environment (VME) or sandbox

rules.name: AD Groups Or Users Enumeration Using PowerShell - ScriptBlock
rules.description:
Adversaries may attempt to find domain-level groups and permission settings.
The knowledge of domain-level permission groups can help adversaries determine which groups exist and which users belong to a particular group.
Adversaries may use this information to determine which users have elevated permissions, such as domain administrators.

rules.name: Suspicious Connection to Remote Account
rules.description:
Adversaries with no prior knowledge of legitimate credentials within the system or environment may guess passwords to attempt access to accounts.
Without knowledge of the password for an account, an adversary may opt to systematically guess the password using a repetitive or iterative mechanism

rules.name: Invoke-Obfuscation RUNDLL LAUNCHER - PowerShell
rules.description: Detects Obfuscated Powershell via RUNDLL LAUNCHER

rules.name: Suspicious Unblock-File
rules.description: Remove the Zone.Identifier alternate data stream which identifies the file as downloaded from the internet.

rules.name: PowerShell Create Local User
rules.description: Detects creation of a local user via PowerShell

rules.name: Powershell Execute Batch Script
rules.description:
Adversaries may abuse the Windows command shell for execution.
The Windows command shell ([cmd](https://attack.mitre.org/software/S0106)) is the primary command prompt on Windows systems.
The Windows command prompt can be used to control almost any aspect of a system, with various permission levels required for different subsets of commands.
Batch files (ex: .bat or .cmd) also provide the shell with a list of sequential commands to run, as well as normal scripting operations such as conditionals and loops.
Common uses of batch files include long or repetitive tasks, or the need to run the same set of commands on multiple system

rules.name: Potential In-Memory Execution Using Reflection.Assembly
rules.description: Detects usage of "Reflection.Assembly" load functions to dynamically load assemblies in memory

rules.name: Execute Invoke-command on Remote Host
rules.description: Adversaries may use Valid Accounts to interact with remote systems using Windows Remote Management (WinRM). The adversary may then perform actions as the logged-on user.

rules.name: Invoke-Obfuscation VAR+ Launcher - PowerShell
rules.description: Detects Obfuscated use of Environment Variables to execute PowerShell

rules.name: Suspicious FromBase64String Usage On Gzip Archive - Ps Script
rules.description: Detects attempts of decoding a base64 Gzip archive in a PowerShell script. This technique is often used as a method to load malicious content into memory afterward.

rules.name: Suspicious Get-ADReplAccount
rules.description:
The DSInternals PowerShell Module exposes several internal features of Active Directory and Azure Active Directory.
These include FIDO2 and NGC key auditing, offline ntds.dit file manipulation, password auditing, DC recovery from IFM backups and password hash calculation.

rules.name: Powershell Suspicious Win32_PnPEntity
rules.description: Adversaries may attempt to gather information about attached peripheral devices and components connected to a computer system.

rules.name: AMSI Bypass Pattern Assembly GetType
rules.description: Detects code fragments found in small and obfuscated AMSI bypass PowerShell scripts

rules.name: WMIC Unquoted Services Path Lookup - PowerShell
rules.description: Detects known WMI recon method to look for unquoted service paths, often used by pentest inside of powershell scripts attackers enum scripts

rules.name: Active Directory Computers Enumeration With Get-AdComputer
rules.description: Detects usage of the "Get-AdComputer" to enumerate Computers or properties within Active Directory.

rules.name: Malicious PowerShell Keywords
rules.description: Detects keywords from well-known PowerShell exploitation frameworks

rules.name: Usage Of Web Request Commands And Cmdlets - ScriptBlock
rules.description: Detects the use of various web request commands with commandline tools and Windows PowerShell cmdlets (including aliases) via PowerShell scriptblock logs

rules.name: Dump Credentials from Windows Credential Manager With PowerShell
rules.description:
Adversaries may search for common password storage locations to obtain user credentials.
Passwords are stored in several places on a system, depending on the operating system or application holding the credentials.

rules.name: Service Registry Permissions Weakness Check
rules.description:
Adversaries may execute their own malicious payloads by hijacking the Registry entries used by services.
Adversaries may use flaws in the permissions for registry to redirect from the originally specified executable to one that they control, in order to launch their own code at Service start.
Windows stores local service configuration information in the Registry under HKLM\SYSTEM\CurrentControlSet\Services

rules.name: Potential Persistence Via Security Descriptors - ScriptBlock
rules.description: Detects usage of certain functions and keywords that are used to manipulate security descriptors in order to potentially set a backdoor. As seen used in the DAMP project.

rules.name: Clearing Windows Console History
rules.description: Identifies when a user attempts to clear console history. An adversary may clear the command history of a compromised account to conceal the actions undertaken during an intrusion.

rules.name: Invoke-Obfuscation VAR+ Launcher - PowerShell Module
rules.description: Detects Obfuscated use of Environment Variables to execute PowerShell

rules.name: Invoke-Obfuscation Obfuscated IEX Invocation - PowerShell Module
rules.description: Detects all variations of obfuscated powershell IEX invocation code generated by Invoke-Obfuscation framework from the code block cited in the reference section below

rules.name: Suspicious Computer Machine Password by PowerShell
rules.description:
The Reset-ComputerMachinePassword cmdlet changes the computer account password that the computers use to authenticate to the domain controllers in the domain.
You can use it to reset the password of the local computer.

rules.name: Suspicious PowerShell Download - PoshModule
rules.description: Detects suspicious PowerShell download command

rules.name: Malicious PowerShell Commandlets - PoshModule
rules.description: Detects Commandlet names from well-known PowerShell exploitation frameworks

rules.name: Suspicious PowerShell Invocations - Specific - PowerShell Module
rules.description: Detects suspicious PowerShell invocation command parameters

rules.name: Use Get-NetTCPConnection - PowerShell Module
rules.description: Adversaries may attempt to get a listing of network connections to or from the compromised system they are currently accessing or from remote systems by querying for information over the network.

rules.name: PowerShell Decompress Commands
rules.description: A General detection for specific decompress commands in PowerShell logs. This could be an adversary decompressing files.

rules.name: Potential RemoteFXvGPUDisablement.EXE Abuse - PowerShell Module
rules.description: Detects PowerShell module creation where the module Contents are set to "function Get-VMRemoteFXPhysicalVideoAdapter". This could be a sign of potential abuse of the "RemoteFXvGPUDisablement.exe" binary which is known to be vulnerable to module load-order hijacking.

rules.name: Bad Opsec Powershell Code Artifacts
rules.description:
focuses on trivial artifacts observed in variants of prevalent offensive ps1 payloads, including
Cobalt Strike Beacon, PoshC2, Powerview, Letmein, Empire, Powersploit, and other attack payloads
that often undergo minimal changes by attackers due to bad opsec.

rules.name: AD Groups Or Users Enumeration Using PowerShell - PoshModule
rules.description:
Adversaries may attempt to find domain-level groups and permission settings.
The knowledge of domain-level permission groups can help adversaries determine which groups exist and which users belong to a particular group.
Adversaries may use this information to determine which users have elevated permissions, such as domain administrators.

rules.name: Invoke-Obfuscation Via Use Clip - PowerShell Module
rules.description: Detects Obfuscated Powershell via use Clip.exe in Scripts

rules.name: Clear PowerShell History - PowerShell Module
rules.description: Detects keywords that could indicate clearing PowerShell history

rules.name: Invoke-Obfuscation Via Use Rundll32 - PowerShell Module
rules.description: Detects Obfuscated Powershell via use Rundll32 in Scripts

rules.name: HackTool - Evil-WinRm Execution - PowerShell Module
rules.description: Detects the execution of Evil-WinRM via PowerShell Module logs by leveraging the hardcoded strings inside the utility.

rules.name: Zip A Folder With PowerShell For Staging In Temp  - PowerShell Module
rules.description:
Detects PowerShell scripts that make use of the "Compress-Archive" Cmdlet in order to compress folders and files where the output is stored in a potentially suspicious location that is used often by malware for exfiltration.
An adversary might compress data (e.g., sensitive documents) that is collected prior to exfiltration in order to make it portable and minimize the amount of data sent over the network.

rules.name: Invoke-Obfuscation RUNDLL LAUNCHER - PowerShell Module
rules.description: Detects Obfuscated Powershell via RUNDLL LAUNCHER

rules.name: PowerShell Get Clipboard
rules.description: A General detection for the Get-Clipboard commands in PowerShell logs. This could be an adversary capturing clipboard contents.

rules.name: Invoke-Obfuscation COMPRESS OBFUSCATION - PowerShell Module
rules.description: Detects Obfuscated Powershell via COMPRESS OBFUSCATION

rules.name: Potential Active Directory Enumeration Using AD Module - PsModule
rules.description: Detects usage of the "Import-Module" cmdlet to load the "Microsoft.ActiveDirectory.Management.dl" DLL. Which is often used by attackers to perform AD enumeration.

rules.name: Suspicious Get Information for SMB Share - PowerShell Module
rules.description:
Adversaries may look for folders and drives shared on remote systems as a means of identifying sources of information to gather as a precursor for Collection and
to identify potential systems of interest for Lateral Movement.
Networks often contain shared network drives and folders that enable users to access file directories on various systems across a network.

rules.name: Remote PowerShell Session (PS Module)
rules.description: Detects remote PowerShell sessions

rules.name: Invoke-Obfuscation Via Use MSHTA - PowerShell Module
rules.description: Detects Obfuscated Powershell via use MSHTA in Scripts

rules.name: Suspicious Get-ADDBAccount Usage
rules.description: Detects suspicious invocation of the Get-ADDBAccount script that reads from a ntds.dit file and may be used to get access to credentials without using any credential dumpers

rules.name: Alternate PowerShell Hosts - PowerShell Module
rules.description: Detects alternate PowerShell hosts potentially bypassing detections looking for powershell.exe

rules.name: Invoke-Obfuscation STDIN+ Launcher - PowerShell Module
rules.description: Detects Obfuscated use of stdin to execute PowerShell

rules.name: Invoke-Obfuscation Via Stdin - PowerShell Module
rules.description: Detects Obfuscated Powershell via Stdin in Scripts

rules.name: SyncAppvPublishingServer Bypass Powershell Restriction - PS Module
rules.description: Detects SyncAppvPublishingServer process execution which usually utilized by adversaries to bypass PowerShell execution restrictions.

rules.name: Suspicious PowerShell Invocations - Generic - PowerShell Module
rules.description: Detects suspicious PowerShell invocation command parameters

rules.name: Invoke-Obfuscation CLIP+ Launcher - PowerShell Module
rules.description: Detects Obfuscated use of Clip.exe to execute PowerShell

rules.name: Suspicious Get Local Groups Information
rules.description:
Adversaries may attempt to find local system groups and permission settings.
The knowledge of local system permission groups can help adversaries determine which groups exist and which users belong to a particular group.
Adversaries may use this information to determine which users have elevated permissions, such as the users found within the local administrators group.

rules.name: Malicious PowerShell Scripts - PoshModule
rules.description: Detects the execution of known offensive powershell scripts used for exploitation or reconnaissance

rules.name: Invoke-Obfuscation VAR++ LAUNCHER OBFUSCATION - PowerShell Module
rules.description: Detects Obfuscated Powershell via VAR++ LAUNCHER

rules.name: Credential Dumping Activity By Python Based Tool
rules.description: Detects LSASS process access for potential credential dumping by a Python-like tool such as LaZagne or Pypykatz.

rules.name: Lsass Memory Dump via Comsvcs DLL
rules.description: Detects adversaries leveraging the MiniDump export function from comsvcs.dll via rundll32 to perform a memory dump from lsass.

rules.name: Credential Dumping Attempt Via Svchost
rules.description: Detects when a process tries to access the memory of svchost to potentially dump credentials.

rules.name: Function Call From Undocumented COM Interface EditionUpgradeManager
rules.description: Detects function calls from the EditionUpgradeManager COM interface. Which is an interface that is not used by standard executables.

rules.name: HackTool - CobaltStrike BOF Injection Pattern
rules.description: Detects a typical pattern of a CobaltStrike BOF which inject into other processes

rules.name: HackTool - LittleCorporal Generated Maldoc Injection
rules.description: Detects the process injection of a LittleCorporal generated Maldoc.

rules.name: Credential Dumping Attempt Via WerFault
rules.description: Detects process LSASS memory dump using Mimikatz, NanoDump, Invoke-Mimikatz, Procdump or Taskmgr based on the CallTrace pointing to ntdll.dll, dbghelp.dll or dbgcore.dll for win10, server2016 and up.

rules.name: HackTool - SysmonEnte Execution
rules.description: Detects the use of SysmonEnte, a tool to attack the integrity of Sysmon

rules.name: CMSTP Execution Process Access
rules.description: Detects various indicators of Microsoft Connection Manager Profile Installer execution

rules.name: HackTool - HandleKatz Duplicating LSASS Handle
rules.description: Detects HandleKatz opening LSASS to duplicate its handle to later dump the memory without opening any new handles

rules.name: Suspicious LSASS Access Via MalSecLogon
rules.description: Detects suspicious access to LSASS handle via a call trace to "seclogon.dll" with a suspicious access right.

rules.name: HackTool - Generic Process Access
rules.description: Detects process access requests from hacktool processes based on their default image name

rules.name: UAC Bypass Using WOW64 Logger DLL Hijack
rules.description: Detects the pattern of UAC Bypass using a WoW64 logger DLL hijack (UACMe 30)

rules.name: LSASS Memory Access by Tool With Dump Keyword In Name
rules.description: Detects LSASS process access requests from a source process with the "dump" keyword in its image name.

rules.name: Potential Credential Dumping Activity Via LSASS
rules.description:
Detects process access requests to the LSASS process with specific call trace calls and access masks.
This behaviour is expressed by many credential dumping tools such as Mimikatz, NanoDump, Invoke-Mimikatz, Procdump and even the Taskmgr dumping feature.

rules.name: Potentially Suspicious GrantedAccess Flags On LSASS
rules.description: Detects process access requests to LSASS process with potentially suspicious access flags

rules.name: Uncommon Process Access Rights For Target Image
rules.description: Detects process access request to uncommon target images with a "PROCESS_ALL_ACCESS" access mask.

rules.name: Potential Direct Syscall of NtOpenProcess
rules.description: Detects potential calls to NtOpenProcess directly from NTDLL.

rules.name: Remote LSASS Process Access Through Windows Remote Management
rules.description: Detects remote access to the LSASS process via WinRM. This could be a sign of credential dumping from tools like mimikatz.

rules.name: Suspicious Svchost Process Access
rules.description: Detects suspicious access to the "svchost" process such as that used by Invoke-Phantom to kill the thread of the Windows event logging service.

rules.name: LSASS Access From Potentially White-Listed Processes
rules.description: Detects a possible process memory dump that uses a white-listed filename like TrolleyExpress.exe as a way to dump the LSASS process memory without Microsoft Defender interference

rules.name: Potential SmadHook.DLL Sideloading
rules.description: Detects potential DLL sideloading of "SmadHook.dll", a DLL used by SmadAV antivirus

rules.name: WMI ActiveScriptEventConsumers Activity Via Scrcons.EXE DLL Load
rules.description: Detects signs of the WMI script host process "scrcons.exe" loading scripting DLLs which could indicates WMI ActiveScriptEventConsumers EventConsumers activity.

rules.name: Potential RjvPlatform.DLL Sideloading From Default Location
rules.description: Detects loading of "RjvPlatform.dll" by the "SystemResetPlatform.exe" binary which can be abused as a method of DLL side loading since the "$SysReset" directory isn't created by default.

rules.name: Active Directory Kerberos DLL Loaded Via Office Application
rules.description: Detects Kerberos DLL being loaded by an Office Product

rules.name: Potentially Suspicious Volume Shadow Copy Vsstrace.dll Load
rules.description: Detects the image load of VSS DLL by uncommon executables

rules.name: PowerShell Core DLL Loaded By Non PowerShell Process
rules.description:
Detects loading of essential DLLs used by PowerShell by non-PowerShell process.
Detects behavior similar to meterpreter's "load powershell" extension.

rules.name: PCRE.NET Package Image Load
rules.description: Detects processes loading modules related to PCRE.NET package

rules.name: Amsi.DLL Loaded Via LOLBIN Process
rules.description: Detects loading of "Amsi.dll" by a living of the land process. This could be an indication of a "PowerShell without PowerShell" attack

rules.name: VBA DLL Loaded Via Office Application
rules.description: Detects VB DLL's loaded by an office application. Which could indicate the presence of VBA Macros.

rules.name: HackTool - SharpEvtMute DLL Load
rules.description: Detects the load of EvtMuteHook.dll, a key component of SharpEvtHook, a tool that tampers with the Windows event logs

rules.name: Unsigned Mfdetours.DLL Sideloading
rules.description: Detects DLL sideloading of unsigned "mfdetours.dll". Executing "mftrace.exe" can be abused to attach to an arbitrary process and force load any DLL named "mfdetours.dll" from the current directory of execution.

rules.name: Microsoft VBA For Outlook Addin Loaded Via Outlook
rules.description: Detects outlvba (Microsoft VBA for Outlook Addin) DLL being loaded by the outlook process

rules.name: Potential Mfdetours.DLL Sideloading
rules.description: Detects potential DLL sideloading of "mfdetours.dll". While using "mftrace.exe" it can be abused to attach to an arbitrary process and force load any DLL named "mfdetours.dll" from the current directory of execution.

rules.name: Suspicious Unsigned Thor Scanner Execution
rules.description: Detects loading and execution of an unsigned thor scanner binary.

rules.name: Potential Wazuh Security Platform DLL Sideloading
rules.description: Detects potential DLL side loading of DLLs that are part of the Wazuh security platform

rules.name: Potential ShellDispatch.DLL Sideloading
rules.description: Detects potential DLL sideloading of "ShellDispatch.dll"

rules.name: Potential DLL Sideloading Via comctl32.dll
rules.description: Detects potential DLL sideloading using comctl32.dll to obtain system privileges

rules.name: Potential DLL Sideloading Via VMware Xfer
rules.description: Detects loading of a DLL by the VMware Xfer utility from the non-default directory which may be an attempt to sideload arbitrary DLL

rules.name: HackTool - SILENTTRINITY Stager DLL Load
rules.description: Detects SILENTTRINITY stager dll loading activity

rules.name: Active Directory Parsing DLL Loaded Via Office Application
rules.description: Detects DSParse DLL being loaded by an Office Product

rules.name: Suspicious WSMAN Provider Image Loads
rules.description: Detects signs of potential use of the WSMAN provider from uncommon processes locally and remote execution.

rules.name: Load Of RstrtMgr.DLL By A Suspicious Process
rules.description:
Detects the load of RstrtMgr DLL (Restart Manager) by a suspicious process.
This library has been used during ransomware campaigns to kill processes that would prevent file encryption by locking them (e.g. Conti ransomware, Cactus ransomware). It has also recently been seen used by the BiBi wiper for Windows.
It could also be used for anti-analysis purposes by shut downing specific processes.

rules.name: Potential DLL Sideloading Of DbgModel.DLL
rules.description: Detects potential DLL sideloading of "DbgModel.dll"

rules.name: Potential DCOM InternetExplorer.Application DLL Hijack - Image Load
rules.description: Detects potential DLL hijack of "iertutil.dll" found in the DCOM InternetExplorer.Application Class

rules.name: Potential DLL Sideloading Of Non-Existent DLLs From System Folders
rules.description:
Detects DLL sideloading of system DLLs that are not present on the system by default (at least not in system directories).
Usually this technique is used to achieve UAC bypass or privilege escalation.

rules.name: Unsigned DLL Loaded by Windows Utility
rules.description:
Detects windows utilities loading an unsigned or untrusted DLL.
Adversaries often abuse those programs to proxy execution of malicious code.

rules.name: Microsoft Excel Add-In Loaded From Uncommon Location
rules.description: Detects Microsoft Excel loading an Add-In (.xll) file from an uncommon location

rules.name: GAC DLL Loaded Via Office Applications
rules.description: Detects any GAC DLL being loaded by an Office Product

rules.name: Potential 7za.DLL Sideloading
rules.description: Detects potential DLL sideloading of "7za.dll"

rules.name: Fax Service DLL Search Order Hijack
rules.description: The Fax service attempts to load ualapi.dll, which is non-existent. An attacker can then (side)load their own malicious DLL using this service.

rules.name: System Control Panel Item Loaded From Uncommon Location
rules.description: Detects image load events of system control panel items (.cpl) from uncommon or non-system locations which might be the result of sideloading.

rules.name: Unsigned Module Loaded by ClickOnce Application
rules.description: Detects unsigned module load by ClickOnce application.

rules.name: Aruba Network Service Potential DLL Sideloading
rules.description: Detects potential DLL sideloading activity via the Aruba Networks Virtual Intranet Access "arubanetsvc.exe" process using DLL Search Order Hijacking

rules.name: Potential SolidPDFCreator.DLL Sideloading
rules.description: Detects potential DLL sideloading of "SolidPDFCreator.dll"

rules.name: DotNET Assembly DLL Loaded Via Office Application
rules.description: Detects any assembly DLL being loaded by an Office Product

rules.name: Potential DLL Sideloading Of MsCorSvc.DLL
rules.description: Detects potential DLL sideloading of "mscorsvc.dll".

rules.name: Potential RjvPlatform.DLL Sideloading From Non-Default Location
rules.description: Detects potential DLL sideloading of "RjvPlatform.dll" by "SystemResetPlatform.exe" located in a non-default location.

rules.name: Potential DLL Sideloading Using Coregen.exe
rules.description: Detect usage of the "coregen.exe" (Microsoft CoreCLR Native Image Generator) binary to sideload arbitrary DLLs.

rules.name: Potential DLL Sideloading Of Libcurl.DLL Via GUP.EXE
rules.description: Detects potential DLL sideloading of "libcurl.dll" by the "gup.exe" process from an uncommon location

rules.name: Potential CCleanerReactivator.DLL Sideloading
rules.description: Detects potential DLL sideloading of "CCleanerReactivator.dll"

rules.name: Wmiprvse Wbemcomn DLL Hijack
rules.description: Detects a threat actor creating a file named `wbemcomn.dll` in the `C:\Windows\System32\wbem\` directory over the network and loading it for a WMI DLL Hijack scenario.

rules.name: Suspicious Unsigned Dbghelp/Dbgcore DLL Loaded
rules.description:
Detects the load of dbghelp/dbgcore DLL (used to make memory dumps) by suspicious processes.
Tools like ProcessHacker and some attacker tradecract use MiniDumpWriteDump API found in dbghelp.dll or dbgcore.dll.
As an example, SilentTrynity C2 Framework has a module that leverages this API to dump the contents of Lsass.exe and transfer it over the network back to the attacker's machine.

rules.name: Potential DLL Sideloading Of DBGHELP.DLL
